Ottawa, October 21st, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, with reference to the equipment, repairs, etc., recommended by the Public School Inspector for the Moraviantown Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that your report regarding these matters has been noted, and it will not be necessary for you to take any action in the matter other than to instruct the teacher to see that the closets are swept from time to time and kept as clean as possible.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Nelson Stone, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Highgate, Ont.

Agent's Report of Session of Moravian Council Feb. 13, 1928.

Agent reported that the locks on outside doors of school house were out of condition and it was impossible to lock these doors at present, and that the doors should be fitted with lock and two keys one for Teacher and other for janitor and in this way building would be locked each night and when no school.

Moved, voted and carried that Chief have these locks installed and furnish the keys to Teacher and Janitor and instruct them to have the last person leaving the building to see that all outside doors were properly locked.

Nelson Stone.
Agent.
Ottawa, February 18, 1928.

Sir:

Relative to your report on the session of the Moravian Council of the 13th instant regarding the placing of locks on the outside doors of the school house, it is noted that instructions have been given to have these locks installed and keys given to the teacher and janitor. The action taken by the Council is approved. The teacher and janitor should see that the school building is locked after classroom hours.

An account, in duplicate, properly certified by you, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

A. F. MacKenzie
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Nelson Stone, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Highgate, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I am enclosing requisition for material for use in the Moravian Day School, Teacher - "Rev. C.W. McKenzie."

Would also ask if Dept. would approve of an expenditure from your Appropriation for Indian Education, for purchasing some perennial shrubbery for border between school yard and Teacher's Residence Lot, and having the fence surrounding the School Ground repaired?

The fence repairs are immediately needed and should be made before the shrubbery is planted, and should think the entire cost of this work and material would not exceed Fifteen or Twenty Dollars.

Please advise me at an early date, as shrubbery should be transplanted very soon if going to be done this Spring.

The shrubbery should beautify the appearance of both school & residence, and be an object lesson to the Indians in the keeping of their home surroundings.

Yours Obediently,

Nelson Stone, Indian Agent.

SEC. DEPT. OF IND. AFF.
OTTAWA, ONT.
Ottawa, May 2, 1928.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 28th ultimo, requesting authority to purchase shrubbery for a border between the school yard and teacher's residence at the Moraviantown Indian Day School, and also for authority to have the repairs required to the fence carried out.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange to have the repairs required to the fence carried out. We note that you estimate the entire cost of this work and material to be approximately $20. The Department will approve of a reasonable expenditure in the purchase of perennial shrubbery for a border between the school yard and teacher's residence, and will rely on you to see that no unnecessary expense is incurred in the purchase of same.

After the repairs to the fence have been made and the shrubbery purchased, please forward certified accounts, in duplicate, in the usual manner covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. McKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Nelson Stone, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Highgate, Ont.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR PEARSON,
dated June 12, 1928, on his inspection
of the MORAVIANTOWN Indian Day School.

Original on File 15-1-6.

The well should be cleaned and a cement
cover should be put on. The outside closets are in very bad con-
dition. New closets are needed at once.
The old double desks are long since out of
date. They should be replaced.
There should be a proper sink and drain
provided.
Ottawa, June 28, 1928.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Moraviantown Indian Day School, states that the outside closets are in very bad condition and that new ones are needed. He also states that the old double desks are long since out of date and should be replaced. Further, he reports that there should be a proper sink and drain provided.

I shall be pleased to have your recommendation regarding the Inspector's suggestions. You should give full particulars regarding the closets, and, if you recommend that new ones be built, please give an estimate of the cost of the material and labour.

Please report, also, regarding the sink and drain, giving an estimate of the cost of any work which you would recommend be carried out.

Relative to the desks, you should state the condition of the double desks at present in use also whether, in your opinion, new single desks are required. If so, full particulars should be given regarding the sizes and the number of each size. When we have your report, consideration will be given as to whether the funds necessary in supplying new desks can be provided or not.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Nelson Stone, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Highgate, Ont.
Replying to Dept. Letter No. 15-1-5 of the 28th ultimo, dealing with report made by Public School Inspector when recently he visited the Moravian Bay School;

I would say that the Inspector should state definitely what sort of closets he would recommend installed; I interviewed the Teacher to see if the Inspector had suggested to him what kind should be installed, and he tells me that the Inspector recommended the chemical closets installed in the basement, but the Teacher told him that these were put in at a former Indian School where he taught, and in less than one year had to be taken out and kept out.

I know of several cases where the Inspector asked to have these installed inside, and later had to be torn out, and it was proved that the Inspector had received a bonus from the Firm that placed them for his service in recommending them.

I think it will be possible to repair the present closets so that they will be satisfactory for a couple or three years, at a cost of not more than $15.00, but would say that by that time something more modern should be erected.

I already have your approval for installing sink and drain, and think it can be done during summer vacation at a cost not to exceed $30.00.

As to desks now in use at this school, they are not modern nor up to date, still it would seem to me sort of extravagant to discard them at present, but possibly it would be wise to include this expenditure in the estimates in the next year or two.

Yours Obediently,

Nelson Stone,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, July 10, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to the report of the Public School Inspector on the condition of the toilets at the Moraviantown Indian Day School. We note that it will be possible to repair the present closets, so that they will be satisfactory for a further period, at a cost of approximately $15. You may arrange to have these closets repaired and placed in a good, sanitary condition. This work should be carried out at the same time as the sink and drain are being installed, and should be completed before the school reopens after the present summer holidays. Please forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

It is noted that the desks can be used for a further period. Should any repairs be required, you may arrange to have same made, so that these desks will be of service for the next school year.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Nelson Stone, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Highgate,
Ont.

Dear Sir,

Received Dept. Letter No. 15-1-5 of the 23rd inst., and would say in reply, that I am going to give you a little explanation in regard to this grant for a treat to the children of Moravian Day School.

Since my appointment as Agent, I have expended from Six to Ten Dollars each year purchasing candy, nuts, oranges & popcorn, and Mrs. Stone got material and made fancy Christmas snacks & ribbons for each pupil, and these were distributed at closing of school for Xmas holidays.

I am pleased to learn that Dept. have agreed to relieve Mrs. Stone & myself from this expenditure of money & time & work.

Rev. C.W. McKenzie wrote me & also interviewed me yesterday on this matter, and I wish to state to Dept. that I can not agree with his method of handling this grant.

He wants, so he tells me, to purchase a treat of candy etc., for some and toys & prizes for others, and have these placed on the Xmas tree of the United Church for distribution, and in this way help their United Church Xmas Entertainment.

There is an Anglican Church on this Reserve, of about same numbers as United Church, and in my opinion any grant from Dept. for distribution of a treat to School, said distribution should take place at school and before close for Xmas holiday.

Furthermore, if candy etc., is purchased for some pupils, toys & other gifts for others, dissatisfaction is sure to result;

I would suggest to have Mr. McKenzie purchase a prize worth one Dollar for the pupil in each form that has been most faithful in attendance during year, and have the balance $12.00 used by me to purchase the same treat for all pupils & Mrs. Stone & I will get the fancy snacks and have prizes & treat distributed at School, by Teacher.

Please advise me at an early date as to your decision in this regard.

Yours Obediently,

Nelson Stone, Ind. Agt.

Would say that I intended to consult with Mr. Wilding on his arrival as to size and number of seats & desks to install at Moravian Day School and try and have these installed during vacation season, but unless he arrives early in August or before, it will be too late to order and have desks & seats delivered & installed before opening of school.

Do not know that it is really necessary or compulsory to do this work just now, nor would it be wise for me to go ahead and do so without consulting with Mr. Wilding.

Rev. Arthur Burner, acting for Home Mission Board of United Church of Canada, has asked me to recommend to Indian Department enlargement & improvement to teacherage, this to be effected as soon as convenient after arrival of Rev. Wilding at Moraviantown; I hesitate to do this, as I feel the present plan combining the teaching & preaching to one individual is not in some respects very satisfactory, and may not be permanent, as the Anglicans are about as strong & numerous in membership as United Church.

However the present residence is far too small for any family, and is constructed in such a way that enlargement is very difficult.

Can not see what was the idea of erecting a house or stable like this one at that date, one story small cottage with cellar under one corner, and too deep for proper drainage of cellar, one small bedroom; Had they put 2 story higher, bedrooms upstairs, it would have cost but little more and now it would not require enlarging; the stable with loft above has never been used only as garage and a garage could have been built at ½ cost of stable;

Would like to be advised at an early date as to what would be your wish in these matters and I will try and carry out your wish;

Yours obediently,

Nelson Stone, Ind. Agent

Ottawa, December 10th, 1929,

Sir:

I inspected the Moravian of Thames Agency on Monday the 25th ultimo and beg to submit the following report.

I visited the one Day school on the reserve. This school is in charge of the Rev. Harold Wilding who is also the Missionary. Twenty-two pupils were present. The teacher reports attendance very good. Emerson Snake, Truant Officer, is an efficient officer and attending to his duties. There is a good live atmosphere in the school. The pupils are a bright healthy looking lot. Agent Stone states that the Rev. Wilding takes a deep interest in the welfare of the pupils at school and in their homes.

Seven pupils from this school are attending vocational and high schools in Chatham and London and are making excellent progress. All the school pupils have been vaccinated.

The school is a brick building and is in very fair condition. The residence in connection with the school has been greatly improved by the addition built last year by the Department. The school and residence is an example of care and tidiness to our Indian people.

There are a few small improvements needed at the school and recommended.

A book case for library books. The teacher has been given a quantity of used books for the use of the pupils and has no place to keep them. A suitable book case could be built locally at a small cost.

A porcelain water container with tap for drinking water for use in the classroom, also ½ doz. drinking cups. These articles can be procured locally by Agent Stone.

If the lower half of the three east windows were frosted or given a coat of white lead, it would improve the light conditions. The teacher is anxious to have this done.

Thos. McGookin,
Inspector.
Ottawa, December 21st, 1929.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, in a report on his visit to the Moraviantown Indian Day School, states that the following are required at this school:

(1) Bookcase for library books. The Inspector states that a suitable bookcase could be built locally at small cost, and I have to request that you will arrange to have a local carpenter build a bookcase of the size required. No unnecessary expense should be incurred or expensive materials used. Locks with keys should be provided for the doors, and the bookcase painted or stained to match the general appearance of the room.

(2) A porcelain water container with tap for use in the classroom, also half a dozen drinking cups. The Inspector states that these articles can be procured locally, and I have to request that you will arrange to purchase a water container of a size and type considered satisfactory, also 6 drinking cups.

(3) The lower half of the three east windows should be frosted or given a coat of white lead. MEMORANDUM:

Plans and specifications have been prepared for the proposed new Church of England School at Onion Lake, Sask.

In planning this building it has been necessary to keep in mind the site which is located on the Onion Lake Reserve approximately 35 miles from a railroad station. The building as planned is of frame construction on a concrete foundation with a low pressure steam system of heating. In the specifications for the building care has been exercised in providing only what is absolutely necessary for the operating of the school. Everything is included in the plans and specifications with the exception of the water supply system for the building, and the sewage disposal system. It is impossible to include these items as we have not sufficient detailed information in order to prepare the necessary plans and specifications.

It is rather difficult owing to the location of the building, as all of the materials have to be transported a distance of 35 miles and ferried across the river, to arrive at an accurate estimate of the cost, but I am of the opinion that the building can be built for approximately $75,000. The plans have been approved by Doctor Westgate and Canon Gould.

Will you please advise me the newspapers in which advertisements may be inserted inviting tenders for this building, I beg to submit for your consideration that we advertise in Edmonton, Calgary and Battleford.

ARCHITECT.
Memorandum,-

Hon. Charles Stewart.

Incl.

I beg to send herewith a memorandum from the Architect of the Department, with reference to the proposed new Church of England school at Onion Lake, Sask. This memorandum is intended to show that your instructions have been followed with reference to the style of building, and the economies practised in designing it.

I shall be glad to receive the names of the papers in Edmonton, Calgary and Battleford in which we are to advertise.

In a day or two I will be sending you a like memorandum with reference to the Roman Catholic boarding school at McIntosh, Ont. These two buildings and the wing to the new building at Kamloops will finish our contract work for this year.

I believe conditions could be improved by supplying a good grade of floor oil and having the floors oiled regularly.
Ottawa, May 22, 1931.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Moraviantown Indian Day School, recommends that the old desks which are stored in the basement of the school be disposed of. He also recommends that the floor of the classroom be oiled regularly.

Relative to the desks, I have to request that you will state whether these old desks are of the single or double type, their condition and what you would advise regarding their disposal.

If you consider that it would improve the floors to have them oiled with a good grade of floor oil, the Department would approve of you arranging to have this done during the coming summer holidays. The floor should first be thoroughly scrubbed and dry before the oil is applied. You may arrange for the purchase of the quantity of oil required and for the labour in having the oil put on the floor. After this work has been done, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Ottawa, March 28, 1934.

Dear Sir,

I inspected the Moravian Agency No. 47, on 19th instant, and beg to submit the following report -

School conditions are satisfactory. The average attendance in most cases is good. The teacher is very capable and energetic young man and takes a personal interest in the community life of the band.

The classroom walls are dingy and patched. They should be painted or calcimined as soon as funds are available. The six window lights on the east side of the classroom if painted over with white lead would give a more comfortable light in the room and do away with the need for window shades. The cost would be negligible.

Thos. McGookin,
Inspector.

Dear Sir,

In connection with voucher #386, in favor of Mr. Beattie for window shades supplied for Moravian Day School, I wish to make some explanation, as follows:

Rev. J.A. Ward, Teacher, reported to me when I visited school early in June, that Inspector had been there the day before and stated three new blinds should be promptly installed to replace three that were badly worn and torn. I immediately asked Mr. Beattie to quote me price of shades of this type, as none of the local dealers carry these shades in stock. He wrote away and ordered 3 shades to match the old ones, and when these arrived, I had received Dept. letter #15-1-5 of June 26/35 where Inspector reported light colored blinds were badly needed for the school; the old shades were very dark as were the three Mr. Beattie had ordered.

I asked Mr. Beattie to return the three new dark ones and have six light colored ones supplied, did this after much consideration and if I have acted wrongly in this matter I am very sorry, but did it for what seemed best to me;

Yours Very Truly,

Nelson Stone,
Indian Agent;

On the 5th ultimo, was submitted to the Department a requisition for school material, in which storm windows for the Moravian Day School was mentioned.

I have inspected these windows, and find the sash very loose, which makes them drafty and cold, especially on windy days. I believe it would be a good investment to supply the school with storm sash; it will not be more comfortable, but a saving of fuel.

There are six windows 5ft IIin by 3ft 9in, which will cost glazed and painted $5.00 each. 25¢ each delivered and 50¢ each installed, a total cost of $34.50.

Mr. Ward, teacher of the Moravian Day School, is requesting a door in the teachers residence.

As one enters the teachers residence, by the front door, there is a hall, on the right there is a door entering the parlor, on the left a door entering the dining room. I will have the labour in connection with the installing of storm windows, and hanging of door, done by an Indian carpenter, who is well qualified to do this work.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 4th ultimo file No.15-1-5, regarding an estimate of repairs to Moravian Day School, as reported by School Inspector.

I might state that Mr. Inspector McGookin is acquainted with these repairs, as I drew his attention to the same on an occasion of a visit to this Agency.

I would estimate an expenditure of $170.00 this would include new steps to front entrance, and new floor on front porch of 2" cedar plank, with concrete bed to carry steps, and concrete side railings to top of porch landing and continuing to School, in order to make footing for porch posts, also a 1½" pipe for center railing. There will be ten, ten inch steps, instead of eight to porch landing. I recommend tearing down porch and closing entrance on the East corner, and filling in door way with the same construction as original, which is brick. On the south corner there is a larger porch and roof, which covers entrance to basement, I would recommend filling in door way, as on East corner, and letting roof of porch down to a proper height, to cover entrance to basement, sealing the same in with material from balance of porch.

As for the furnace the janitor made some minor repairs last winter, which put all in fair shape. Highgate July 12th, 1939,

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of June 15th Department file No. I5-I-5, regarding repairs and improvements to Moravian Day School.

I would suggest the two side entrances of the school be closed, which will require about 300 brick, it will be necessary to plaster the inside and fill with new wainscoting where doors are removed. The chimney of the school is in a dangerous condition and needs repairing. It will require about 8 or 10 courses of brick removed from the top, and built straight up the same as the main body of the chimney, the top projects out and bricks are falling out, the top to be covered with a 4" concrete cap. I can have this work done by a reliable contractor for $47.00 material supplied, the most work in regards to repairing the chimney will be building a scaffold.

The porch and steps on the North East side to be removed, also the South West side steps to be removed and porch to be lowered to make a porch over entrance to basement, this work can be done by Fred Stonefish an Indian of the Band well qualified to do the work, and is available @ 25¢ per hour.
I would also like to build a new fence around the school yard, which will require 60 rods of fencing and I would recommend a No. 9 gauge, 9 wire, 47" high, with 12 uprights to the rod. This fence, either a Frost or Lundy fence will cost 73¢ per rod. It will require thirty cedar posts for corner posts, braces, and gate posts, and 30 steel posts, the large corner posts and gate posts which will require 19 posts @ 40¢ each, 11 small braces @ 25¢ each and 30 steel posts @ 51¢ each, also 33 lbs of brace wire @ 6¢ per lbs and 50¢ worth of staples, making a total cost of material $72.10¢. I recommend steel posts due to so many trees around the yard, which will be a saving in labour digging holes, the fence row along the back of the school is hedge of large pine trees, and here there is practically no fence at all, these trees was never trimmed and are dangerous on account of grass fires.

Perhaps I can arrange to have old fence removed for old posts and portion of fence that might be of any use. The fence also can be built by Indian labour, and 20¢ per hour. I would estimate all Indian labour at around $40.00.

If these arrangements meet with the approval of the Department, I would be pleased with an accountable advance of $50.00 to take care of Indian labour in connection with this expenditure.

Your obedient servant,

Stuart Spence

Highgate November 30th, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I wish to refer you to official letters of April 6th, 1936 and February 15th, 1938, dealing with new desks for the Moravian Bay School.

During this last month there has been an average attendance at school of 35 pupils, some days there has been as many as 42 children present, and only 37 seats. I would recommend that seven No. 3 single desks be supplied to take care of the increased attendance.

I also wish to inform you that the teacher is badly in need of blackboard space; at present there is a blackboard across the back of the school room, and about 10 ft. on each side making about 200 sq. ft. of space. There was 14 ft. more blackboard space on the east side of the room covering the bottom of three windows on that side, and I would recommend that this be replaced. I am of the opinion that these three windows should be closed and a window made on the west side in the north corner. I would be pleased if an official of the Department could see the situation before anything was done so that it could be made permanent.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

In reference to your letter of December 4th, 1939 Department file No. 15-1-5 in regards to an estimate of the cost of closing three windows on the East side of the Moravian school room and opening a window on the west side, I would estimate this alteration would cost $100.00.

Since recommending this alteration and upon the receipt of your letter asking for this estimate, I have made enquiries of Mr. Pearson, School Inspector, and a school board that made these alterations, and I have formed an opinion that by carrying out the above mentioned alterations there would be insufficient light. The Inspector informed me that there should be lighting space a fifth of the floor space of the class room.

The Moravian school room is much larger than the average rural school it being 26½ x 31 ft long, and in order to comply with the Inspectors views five windows on the east side of the school would not be a fifth of the floor space, and would take up all the space of the west side of the building. Mr. Pearson is making a further inspection in the near future and is making a report of his views in this matter. I would be pleased with his report before any further action was taken, as he has had considerable experience of this nature in his districts.

If window lighting is not sufficient perhaps artificial lights could be used, as they are available.

Dear Sir:

I have been interviewed, and requested by Mrs. R.J. Ross the Moravian Day School teacher, to take up the matter of sinking a water well for the use of the teachers residence. Mr. and Mrs. Ross as well as other Missionaries have had to use water from the school well, which is a community well, in fact it is used by every one, and in a lot of cases not in a very sanitary way. Mrs. Ross has had each school child supply themselves with a water cup, as a prevention of spreading disease.

You will note in Dr. D.L. Stewart's monthly reports and accounts that syphilis is quite prevalent, and among those who have no other source of water supply other than the school. The children as well as adults continually drink water from the well by using their hand under the pump spout; this practice has been discouraged with some success.

I would be pleased with the authority of the Department to sink a surface well for the use of the residence. I am sure a surface well could be had for the digging. I estimate this would require an expenditure of approximately $50.00 which would include digging, bricklaying, pump and plumbing.

Your obedient servant,

Stuart Spence,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

In connection with the attached vouchers I have to refer you to my letter of July 4th, and your letter of July 10th, Department file No. 15-1-5.

It will be noted that I intended that Indian labour would be used putting new roof on Moravian Day School.

As required in purchasing order No. 3029, Chas Hubbell of Thamesville delivered these shingles to the school in July, and it was not until in September that Indian Stonefish started the roof; he layed 5 bundles as covered by voucher No. 166 and did no more. In October started Indian Logan shingling at Stonefish request; he layed 14 bundles and would do no more, saying it was too cold, therefore I had to hire a white man to complete the job due to it being so late in the season.

I am sorry for this work was not done as planned, and trust it meets with your approval.

Extract from Inspector Pearson's report on the Moravian Indian Day School visited on April 29, 1941.

As I pointed out in my last report, the dust is very bad. Some form of dust layer should be provided. The caretaker should be required to scrub the floor at least monthly. In general the work of the caretaker is only fair. The steps are in a dangerous condition. They should be repaired at once. The furnace should be repaired or replaced. Additional hooks should be provided for the cloakrooms.
Ottawa,
May 6, 1941.

Dear Sir:

In reporting on his inspection of the Moravian Indian Day School on the 29th ultimo Inspector Pearson states that the steps are in a dangerous condition and require immediate repairs. He also recommends that the furnace be repaired and that additional hooks be provided for the cloakrooms.

You may purchase the hooks that are needed and you may arrange for the repairs to the steps. Please let me know what it would cost to repair the furnace.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. S. Spence,
Indian Agent,
Highgate, Ont.
Highgate June 12th, 1941

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of May 6th Department file No. 15-1-5, regarding Inspector Pearson's report of repairs to Moravian Day School.

Regarding repairs to the school steps, they will have to be replaced by new ones, of which I have had Mr. Chas Hubbell of Thamesville Ontario local contractor give an estimate of the cost; at present the school steps are to seep, and I suggest a longer set of steps, of which Mr. Hubbell will install for $65.00, this will include 9, 7½" risers and one cement bottom seep. The wooden steps are to be two, 2 x 6 cedar planks 10 ft. long, this is to be set on a cement foundation and given two coats of paint, also side railings.

Mr. N.A. Sharp of the Engineering Construction Service of the Department visited the Agency recently and approved of the above.

In reference to the school furnace, I have to state that this is a very old furnace and just what is wrong with it. "I am unable to say the only complaint I have is that it smokes this no doubt could be stopped, I am of the opinion this old furnace is just as good as any furnace for burning wood, and wood is all that is used, I would like to report later concerning this matter.

While Mr. Sharp was here
While Mr Sharp was here I had him take measurements of the school with the view of painting inside and out. Mrs Ross the teacher has arranged to have the Indian School teachers convention here this Fall, and we would like to be looking our best; would appreciate your approval of these expenditures.

Yours obedient servant,

Stuart Spence,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa Canada.
Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant with reference to the new steps at the Moravian Indian Day School. The amount mentioned in your letter, namely, $65.00, appears rather high for a set of steps for an Indian day school. Your letter is not exactly clear but I am of the impression that you are building a platform 10' long. Why is it necessary to supply a platform of such length?

With reference to the exterior and interior painting of the school you should let me have an estimate of its cost, also a requisition for the material required, and a decision will then be made regarding the matter.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of June 17th Department file No.15-1-5 regarding new steps for the Moravian Day School.

First I wish to state there is no platform being built, the steps lead up to a porch covering the front entrance of the school. This porch has a floor which is in good condition other than paint.

The material for the steps alone will cost in the neighbourhood of $35.00, the steps are 10 ft. wide, this is the width of the porch. In my letter of June 12th regarding this matter I recommended a longer set of steps, than the old ones, as they are too steep, this requires new concrete foundation, which adds considerably to the cost.

New steps can be built on the old foundation which will reduce the cost, I would estimate about $30.00 or perhaps more.

Regarding the exterior and interior of painting the school I estimate it will require about 12 or 15 gallons of paint for two coats inside and out, at an estimated cost of $60.00, being $4.00 per gallon for 15 gallons. Estimate labour at $125.00 this will include washing the ceiling and walls of the interior, and outside wood work cleaned and brushed before painting.

The Secretary,

Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa Canada.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

The pump at the Moravian Day School has become beyond repairs; this pump and well is used by several families living near the school, and has been kept in repairs mostly by the local residence.

A new "Beatty No.2 pump complete with 5 ft. of 2" pipe and a 3/8" x 10" cylinder will cost delivered $14.00; an additional 5 ft. of 2" pipe required from the cylinder to the proper depth in the well can be taken off the old pump. I would be pleased with the approval of this expenditure and an additional $2.00 be allowed to cover the cost of installing if necessary, making a total cost of $16.00.

In the Moravian Day School are two cupboards used to store supplies and text-books; these are not sufficient. Mr. Dodson the teacher has suggested two shelves running the length of the room under the windows on the west side of the school. This will require 40 running feet of 1" x 12" pine boards, and 12 brackets; the lumber will cost 7¢ per ft. and the brackets 35¢ per pair, making a total of $14.90. This Mr. Dodson will install, and we would like to have them installed so that they could be painted while the school is being painted.

Your obedient servant,

Stuart Spence,
Indian Agent.

July 15-1-5 July 28.

When I used the word 'deplorable' in reference to the furnace in the Moraviantown Day School I did not mean that it was beyond redemption but that it is in a state that requires attention. The school was redecorated just two years ago and the walls are almost as black as ever now. The furnace SMOKEs. When Mr. Doucet was here he remarked about it.

The furnace has been repaired several times in the past years. In fact one dealer told me he had done it. During Mrs. Ross' term she had the same trouble—SMOKE—

The furnace, perhaps, could be repaired. As I stated in my letter it is getting more and more difficult to get wood. The supply on the reserve is getting low. Men are difficult to find to cut it. This year we are lacking NINE CORDS in next season's supply.

If we had a combination coal and wood furnace we would be ready for such an emergency. I appreciate the fact that coal is hard to secure, i.e. Hard Coal.

I am enclosing an estimate I have received today from Mr. Grant. You will note it is the same as Mr. Hubbell's and which I said seemed to be the most satisfactory. The price is lower. Now why did I say this? In putting up a shelter over our cellar entrance we got cheaper lumber and it is very inferior material. We get what we pay for. The best is generally the cheapest in the long run. I considered the highest priced the best.
The present furnace is bolted and these become burned off, parts separate, cracks appear, SMOKE, ASHES and DUST are sent into class-room and heat is digested. The newer ones are not bolted but are fused together. There are no gates in the present furnace. Have been burned out no doubt.

In my opinion the $290 estimate is much too expensive.

If the Department thinks the present furnace can be repaired with consideration of wood supply in the future might be a factor.

I trust I have made things clear and that the department will be able to do something for us.

Acting Indian Agent.

P.S. I enclose copy of Mr. Hubbell's estimate ON THE SAME FURNACE. You will note that Mr. Grant's estimate is about $30.00 lower. I would therefore recommend that if the Dept. considers putting in a furnace that Mr. Grant's estimate be accepted.

REPORT ON MORAVIAN INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF OCTOBER, 1944.

The drainage system from the zink of the Moravian Bay School was repaired. I found this to be a very short drain, draining into a stone pile in the ground. I removed the stones and tile and built a cesspool five feet in the ground, had a galvanized pipe put direct from the zink to the cesspool. I believe this will be a permanent job.

The school furnace has been repaired and I am pleased to report that it is practically as good as new. The expense in this connection was more than I expected, but new castings was necessary to make it in good shape. The eavestroughs repairs of the teacherage was completed this required more eavestroughing than I estimated. When we started removing the old, we found more that should come off.

I have your letter of November 2nd, 1944 file No. 15-1-5 in reference to my voucher No. 177 for expenditures in connection with the Moravian Day School and teacherage.

On Mr. Arneils visit May 22nd, 1944 he authorized some new eavetroughing for the teachers residence, the furnace of the Day School repaired and two tons of coal supplied the school, no stated amount was authorized as it was hard to estimate the cost of these repairs. I thought at the time 20 or 30 feet of eavetroughing would put the system of the teacherage in fair shape, but when Mr. Grant got to taking it down more was eaten with rust than I had first thought, about three years ago these eavetroughs was painted, the school furnace was in very poor condition, there was continual reports of it smoking, and there was parts after we had it tore down that was burnt and warped so bad that repairs could not be made other than replacing them with new parts, for instance the large top casting that cost $16.54 was warped in such a shape, that the damper could not be closed with the results it would burn out the damper in a short time, we haven't had a damper on this account for a long time, the outside jacket or casing was beyond repairs and had to be replaced, this is now double with an asbestos lining between, the grates had to be replaced, and the grate frames was warped so that they had to be removed and corrected in order that the grates could be worked, the fire box was all recentered and I would say the furnace is practically as good as new.

APPENDIX TO SCHOOL LIGHTING REPORT

This appendix forms an essential part of the lighting recommendation

GENERAL CONSIDERATIONS

Benefits of Adequate Lighting

The necessity of adequate lighting in classrooms has been thoroughly established by scientific research and by actual experience. The cost of installing a good lighting system is small compared to the benefits accruing from it. Some of these benefits are: minimized eye strain, clear seeing from all parts of the room, increased efficiency of teacher, independence of variations in daylight, better progress and fewer examination failures, greater benefits to pupils with subnormal eyes, better discipline, and more cheerful surroundings.

Requirements of the System

The principal requirements of classroom lighting is that it shall provide evenly distributed illumination of adequate intensity for all desks, with sharp shadows minimized and with the least possible glare.

Types of Lighting

There are three types of lighting that may be used for classrooms. The selection will be influenced chiefly by the cost of the fixtures, the provision for cleaning them regularly, and the maintenance of the ceiling in good reflecting condition.

Indirect Tungsten Lighting. See plate 2, groups 1 and 2.

This is produced by projecting light to the ceiling from which it is distributed throughout the room. Consequently the ceiling MUST be maintained in a highly reflective condition: white or near white.

Indirect lighting involves the use of an inverted bowl or reflector of some sort. Therefore, the dust that collects in them MUST be cleaned out regularly and frequently. Wiping with a dry cloth once a month, and washing at least three times during the school season should be sufficient for ordinary conditions. This is particularly important in rural schools.
The quality of properly designed and installed indirect lighting is excellent—softly diffused light that is beneficial to the eyes.

**Semi-direct Tungsten Lighting.** See plate 2, group 4.

This lighting is produced by enclosing-glass units; No. 1, group 4 is of prismatic glass; units 2 to 5 are of white or milk glass. White glass units to comply with these recommendations must be greater in diameter than in depth.

Semi-direct fixtures are satisfactory if they are of the specified size and shape, and suspended at the specified height.

The lighting is somewhat less refined in quality than indirect, but does not depreciate quite as rapidly from the accumulation of dust or discoloration of the ceiling.

**Fluorescent Lighting.**

This is the newest form of lighting. Its higher efficiency makes possible the higher intensities of illumination that are so desirable, without increasing the cost of power used. The only fixtures that should be used in classrooms are those in which no bare tubular lamps are visible from normal viewing angles.

In school the pupils spend a considerable amount of time looking straight ahead at the blackboard or the teacher. If bare lamps are exposed to view the glare would be objectionable.

Properly planned fluorescent lighting of reasonably high intensity surpasses ordinary tungsten lighting in quality.

When fluorescent lighting is to be used on 25 cycle power, the utmost care is needed in the selection of fixtures that will minimize the flicker that is caused by the 25 cycle power.

**Relative Cost.**

Fluorescent lighting is very much higher in first cost than tungsten lighting, particularly in 25 cycle districts. Indirect tungsten is next, and semi-direct tungsten the lowest.
BLACKBOARD LIGHTING

It is most important that all the pupils be able to see distinctly the work that is written on the blackboards. Most blackboards reflect glaring light that prevents clear seeing. The most effective way of overcoming this is to shade the windows that admit the glaring light and illuminate the blackboards by supplementary units installed especially for the purpose.

Maintenance

All lighting fixtures collect dust, particularly indirect fixtures of any kind. Dust absorbs and wastes light. This wasted light is paid for but not received. Cleaning of lighting equipment is just as necessary to a lighting system as lubrication to an automobile.

Do not let the ceiling become dull with age. Dark ceilings increase glare and reduce the efficiency of the ceiling.

ALLOWANCE FOR DEPRECIATION

In the preparation of this recommendation an allowance has been made for natural depreciation of the lamps and the accumulation of dust on the lighting equipment between cleaning periods. The lighting will therefore appear higher in intensity when the system is new than it will after a few months' use.

WIRING

The importance of adequate wiring is evident from the fact that a 10% voltage loss, due to inadequate current-carrying capacity, will cause a light loss of approximately 24%. Where the wire sizes are not noted on the lighting plan there is a table on the drawing which specifies minimum sizes. These sizes are based on a maximum voltage loss of 2%, which is in accordance with good wiring practice. (In no case should wire smaller than No. 12 B & S Gauge be used for branch circuits).

WINDOW SHADES

Attention is directed to the proper use of window shades. They are installed particularly to shield the desks near the windows from direct sunlight.

It is only under the MOST favourable conditions that the desks farthest from the windows receive fair daylight illumination. When the window shades are drawn over the upper half of
the windows, the illumination on desks farthest from the windows may be decreased 60% or more, depending upon local conditions.

CONCLUSION

This plan has been carefully prepared for this particular school. Emphasis is placed on the importance of providing lighting in accordance with present-day standards. REDUCTION OF THE NUMBER OF FIXTURES, OR THE SUBSTITUTION OF SMALLER LAMPS OR INFERIOR LIGHTING EQUIPMENT WILL RESULT IN INFERIOR LIGHTING THAT WILL NOT PRODUCE THE DESIRED RESULTS. The following steps are necessary in order to take full advantage of the benefits of better lighting.

1. Install the lighting outlets as indicated.
2. Insist on adequate wiring with wire sizes shown on the drawing.
3. Install only mogul-socket fixtures for classroom lighting (for tungsten lamps).
4. Select the type and size of fixture specified.
5. All electrical work must be approved by your District Electrical Inspector.

I am herewith enclosing for the approval of the Department, a requisition for four (4) school desks, and I wish to report that while we have 44 seats and 45 desks we have 48 on the roll. September 6th, there was 45 children present today. Mr. Dodson had to arrange a bench for three children from some rough boards.

There is room for three desks, and we have one desk without a seat; therefore I would recommend we be supplied with one (1) seat Glebe No. 3 and three (3) desks Glebe No. 2.

Individual drinking cups have been supplied and are used by the children, 42 of these are on hand, and I would be pleased to be authorized to purchase 6 more at a cost of 7¢ each.

In 1935 electric service was made available on the Moravian Indian Reserve, the churches, teachers residence, Council Hall and other buildings in connection with the Moravian Agriculture Society was wired for electric lights. This project has been successfully administered and enjoyed by all. During the time of installing electric service, the writer had proposed that the Moravian Day School be wired, this did not meet with the approval of the Department.

During the past winter the school children and adults received much good and enjoyed once a month in the school room educational films sponsored by the National Film Board. This required a cord strong from the teachers residence some 150 feet from the school to operate the projector. This practice is not only unhandy but dangerous. I have been advised that early this fall and continuing through the winter the Film Board are renewing this service throughout the district, and are arranging their schedule to call at the Moravian Day School once a month, also that films are available to the teacher for educational purposes upon application.

Mr. Dodson, the day school teacher, has a projector ordered and expects it in September. Mr. Dodson is doing this himself that is getting the projector for his own use, of which he is going to use on the Reserve for educational purposes.

Could it be possible at this time to have the school wired for electric lights, not only for the use of a projector but for lighting the school on dark days, electric service could be used to advantage in Vocational training of which is carried on under Mr. Dodson with a great deal of interest and success among the Moravian children.

over
The Electric service line is 150 feet from the school, and I would estimate the cost of installing the service in the school at around $100.00 with the approval of the Department I would be pleased to get tenders from Local electricians to do this work, submitting the same to the Department for their approval.

Stuart Spence,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Neary,

In reference to your letter of August 26th, Department file No. 15-1-5W, in reply to my letter of August 15th, regarding wiring the Moravian Day School for electric service.

I have contacted four local electricians, regarding tenders for this work, but in each case I have been advised that they have far more work than they can do with the material available to them.

Mr. Norman Evans of Ridgetown a well qualified electrician looked over the job and roughly estimated the cost around $150.00 and said he would let me know what he could do the job for providing he could get material, later he phoned me stating he was unable to get supplies, apparently at this time a complete job is impossible.

Recently I have contacted the above electrician with the view of him installing the service and necessary wiring for a projector for visual training, this he verbally agreed to do at around $60.00, this will be a three wire service from the existing line, some two hundred feet from the school, installing service meter and whatever necessary equipment required for the projector, leaving everything in shape to install lights, receptacles, switches, at a later date.

With the Department's approval I would be pleased to employ Mr. Evans at time and material, he is a good workman and I am sure the cost will not be much over the $60.00.

Re: Moravian Day School

In 1941 the Moravian Day School was redecorated both inside and out, and the outside is in fairly good condition, except the entrance landing and steps, the interior of the school is badly soiled, especially the walls and ceilings.

I have had a decorator look over the job, and he offered to contract the work which is to wash the walls and ceiling, of the class room, the entry, and the boys and girls cloak rooms, and put on two coats of the best grade paint, refinish the blackboards, repaint the two cupboards, paint the inside doors of the entry and cloak rooms, the entrance landing and steps for $150.00.

The School Inspector recommends a bright ceiling and light green walls, the class room is 30 by 26, 7 ft wall, there is a four foot wainscoat, which is in good condition, the entry and two cloak rooms are 9 x 6 ft. with a 7 ft ceiling above the wainscoat.

Varney and Bailey are the decorators, and are redecorating the Highgate, High and Continuation school, as well as several other schools in the district.

I recommend and would be pleased with the approval of having this work done.

Stuart Spence,
Indian Agent.
Extract from Inspector F.L. Barrett's report on the Moravian Indian Day School, dated June 10th, 1947. Original on 15-1-6

"The classroom is beginning to show the need for redecoration. It is hoped that it can be done this summer and I would suggest the ceiling be white with the walls in very pale green or blue and the stove and pipes aluminum.

I note that it is now possible to have electric lights in the school and trust that it is intended to do the installing this summer. The room will require six drops, with eighteen-inch globes and 500 watt bulbs.

The shingles do not look too good in spots and the roof should be checked for leaks.

The toilets require some repairs and I would recommend the provision of toilet paper as well as lime or ashes to keep the odour down."

It would be well to have screens for the windows so the windows can be put up without the fly nuisance."

On Mr. Neary's recent visit to this Agency the possibility of obtaining the Moravian Orange Hall on the Reserve, for a Junior Class room to accommodate children of the Moravian Day School was discussed; it was left to the writer to rent or buy the hall if possible.

At a meeting of the Orange Lodge held on the evening of October 13th, I visited the Lodge for this purpose; there were six Lodgemen present five being members of the Band. I approached them on the possibility of renting the hall for a year or up to a five year term, preferable a five year term, so that the Department could have ample time to build a new class room. I offered them $10.00 per month which appeared to be satisfactory. I offered to purchase the hall, and they asked $2000.00 for it. I did not make them any offer as I thought they were asking too much for it. I promised them we would redecorate the Hall, and arrange to allow them to use the Hall for their monthly meetings. Considerable discussion arose over them wanting to use the Hall for dancing, and religious gatherings. I left the meeting without obtaining their permission to use it, but they were going to discuss it further, and would let me know the results. I understand one other Lodge member came later in the evening, and the proposition was turned down.

Mr. Arneil visited the Reserve November 5th, and he took this matter up with Fred Stonefish an active Orangeman and leader of his people. He promised Mr. Arneil that he would take this matter up again at their meeting in November 10th, and suggested to Mr. Stonefish that we would give them $15.00 for a two year lease, and he has reported to me that he was unable to convince the members to lease the Hall.
At a regular meeting of the Moravian Band Council November 10th, this question was discussed at some length, the Chief and Council was surprized and concerned as to why the Orange Lodge would not cooperate in this matter. Therefore it was resolved that the Council Hall be used for a Class room, of which I can with some expense, and a saving over the other proposition make a comfortable class room.

The Council hall is rather large, inside measurements are 48 feet long and 30 feet wide, I would suggest a black board 28 feet long be placed on the North West side, beginning at the west corner or the front of the hall, sixteen Jr. seats or desks be taken from the school and attached to narrow boards so they will not be fastening them to the hall floor, and with this arrangement they can be moved to one side, so that the hall could be used for other purposes if needed, half dozen new Jr. desks supplied along with a teachers desk and chair, a cupboard should be built for supplies, and if the Department see fit eight kindergarten chairs and two tables. We might find it hard to heat in the extremely cold weather, for very little, a partition could be put up for very little, taking 20 or 25 feet off the back of the hall.

Providing this arrangement meets with the approval of the Department, I would be pleased with the materials required, and authority to make as suitable class room as possible, and directions in obtaining a teacher, we will need 20 cords of wood, this will be 24 inch wood, there is hydro in the school, and we might be responsible for the electric account, there is a piano in the hall that will be available to a music teacher.

I regret very much in not obtaining the Orange Lodge cooperation in this matter, there excuse to me was if they rent their hall their Lodge will cease to exist.

Stuart Spence,
Indian Agent.

Moravian Indian Day School.

I have for answer your letter of November 14th, concerning arrangements which you have made for the opening of a second classroom in the Council Hall. It is regretted that you were unable to get the Orange Hall but the Department sincerely appreciates your action and that of the Band Council in allowing us to use the Council Hall for a classroom.

We have today ordered the following equipment for the new classroom:

(a) Twenty eight feet blackboard,
(b) Six Desks, small,
(c) One Teacher's Desk
(d) Eight Kindergarten Chairs
(e) Two Kindergarten tables.

Authority is given for the local purchase of:

(a) One Teacher's Chair
(b) Twenty cords wood (If you will advise us of the price per cord we will forward you an accountable advance.

You can also obtain an estimate for the erection of a partition as you suggested.

With regard to the hydro, will the Council request rent for this building or would it be agreeable to them if we met the hydro account in lieu.
I can not guarantee a delivery date on the desks as they are in very short supply and we are experiencing considerable difficulty in having our orders filled. At the present time delays of eight weeks are normal before orders are completed.

With regard to a teacher, I had one but she wanted immediate employment and I thought we would place her at Caughmawaga where one of our teachers will shortly be retiring because of ill health. However, if you will let us know the names of local papers in which we could insert advertisements, I will be glad to arrange for the publication of a teacher wanted ad. Unless, of course, there is someone whom you or Mr. Dodson have in mind, I am writing to Doctor Dorey of the United Church.

As advised you recently, we have included a sum in our Estimates to cover the building of a one-room Indian Day School and attached teacher's residence to replace the temporary quarters being rented now at Moraviantown.

I have your letter of February 26th, file No. 413-5, in reference to the construction of a new school on the Moravian Indian Reserve, enclosing Plan and Specifications of school and teacher's quarters No. 885, and project information forms, of which are herewith completed in duplicate.

It will be noted I have suggested a basement under the teachers quarters, this is I believe is essential, and is part of the curriculum in education to Indians, in the choice of the two locations, drainage can be made good with a couple hundred tile, in fact there is natural drainage.

The firm Wheeler Builders Supplies, appears for supplies of all materials, there are several others firms in the district but it so happened during the past two years when approximately $15,000.00 was expended in repairs to buildings on the Reserve under the Veterans Land Act, and the other firms supplied all the materials except the Wheeler Lumber Co., this was due mostly to the fact they were new in the district and not as well known to the Indians, as the other firms, and the writer thought this would even up the distribution among all.

The carpenter foreman suggested received his initial training as a carpenter in the Siggwaith Indian Residential School, and has been quite successful, one other Indian who has received a course of training through the Department of Veterans Affairs, and several others who are natural carpenters and are working at the trade for a living.

Further reference to water supply
Further reference to water supply, by installing a pressure system to our present water supply at the Senior Day School, both schools and both teacherage's could have running water.

In reference to the location of the new school site, the plan of the Moravian Indian Reserve dated August 20th, 1900, indicates the school as being on Lot No. 43; this is an old school site, our present Day School and teachers residence is on the extreme south part of Lot No. 42, and I suggest that we purchase the balance of the land which I estimate to be an acre, or an acre off the north 5 acres of Lot No. 55, the latter is a bit complicated as it is involved in the settlement of an estate. The former gives us the proper site designed by the Architect, with your approval I will enter into an agreement with Norman Stonefish Locatee of the South Half of Lot No. 42, held under Location Ticket No. 5890, and purchase the piece of land the depth of our present school site, and the width from our present school site west to the line between Lots No. 42 and 41, as indicated on the attached sketch.

Stuart Spence,
Agency Superintendent.

Moraviantown Indian Day School.

I have your letter of March 18th file No. 413-5 in reference to the construction of a new school, and plan No. 365 a more costly school than plan No. 388. Plan No. 365 appears to be the most favourable of the two, and I trust there is a complete bill of materials for this school. I have no doubt that I have sufficient qualified labour on the Reserve to do the job.

In the course of a week or ten days, depending on the weather, it is planned to have an excavator on the Reserve in connection with a drainage scheme, and if it could be arranged, we could have our basement dug quite easily at that time. There is also a bulldozer coming with this outfit that could level the building site and school grounds permanently.

There is another little thought that might be considered. At the Caradoc Agency I understand the Department have a cement mixer, and wheelbarrows, that might be loaned us for this project, also we might have the use of a truck.

"Upon the receipt of your telegram I was able to stop the excavator and bulldozer which was ready to leave the Reserve, and as I write they have the job half done, unfortunately it is quite wet yet on our sandy soil, and at a depth of four feet water is seeping in fast this will give us some trouble for a while, the excavation work is being done at $35 per yard, and $8.00 per hour for bulldozing, of which will cost less than $150.00, we might not be able to complete bulldozing at this time on account of water, but later when it dries up this machine will be back to finish leveling dirt along the drains just dug, I think this is much better than attempting it ourselves.

But there is the question of the water seeping in of which I would like to immediately or as soon as possible put weeping tile in as per plan.

In ordering cement for this building it would be appreciated if an additional 75 lbs could be ordered for veterans under the Veterans Land Act, which will be paid for from their grants, for the repairs to their homes and other buildings, I have ordered this cement but it appears, that delivery is not going to be made.

It was suggested by Mr. Moris that we inspect the construction of the new schools being built at Caradoc, I am planning on taking my foreman and two carpenters there tomorrow, we hope to have a visit with the building contractor at this time, and other Indian carpenters."

Ottawa, April 26, 1949.

Memorandum:

Colonel B. F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Re: New School - Moravian Indian Agency.

Superintendent Stuart Spence has already submitted a recommendation to your office that the construction of the new school on the above Reserve be done under the supervision of a capable Indian carpenter-foreman with Indian labour.

I interviewed the Indian Superintendent Spence has in mind and he appears to be trustworthy and talks as if he has sufficient knowledge to undertake this work.

I would suggest that Mr. Spence's proposals be approved and that the Purchasing Agent be requested to obtain all the materials for early delivery. I understand he has already had the cellar excavated. So that his job may proceed without interruption, I would recommend that he be authorized to purchase locally the lumber required to construct the forms for the cellar. The cost should not, in my opinion, exceed $100. Arrangements have been made with Superintendent F. L. Hall, of Caradoc Indian Agency, to send his cement mixer to the Moravian Indian Reserve to be used in running the cement for the foundation. It is, therefore, imperative that the cement be bought and delivered at the earliest possible date.

The work on the above school, as suggested in my memorandum of even date on file A17-9, should be supervised occasionally by Mr. Mahler, the carpenter-foreman, and if this is done, it should be possible to avoid a number of building difficulties as he, to my way of thinking, is capable and familiar with the construction of this type of school.

J. E. Morris,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies for the Province of Ontario.

Moraviantown Indian Day School

I have for reply your letter of April 15th file No. 413-5 in reference to your telegram, in connection with the School site, excavation, and the ability of the carpenter foreman, as reported in my letter of April 12th I was able to have the excavation work done, and the grounds partly leveled, the grounds was to wet to complete bulldozing, of which will be completed at a later date.

As I write we have 2½ feet of water in the basement, but I have taken the liberty to have it tiled and expect to complete the job today, this will be a tile drain other than specified in the plan. Three rods from the school site, there is a six inch tile running along the side of the road draining the old school and teacherage, and I am tapping into this, we are well below the basement wall footings so that the drain will not interfere with construction, it has abundance of fall and will give us good drainage.

In further reference to the six inch tile drain we are tapping into, it is in need of repairs, and an immediate drainage must be given to the excavation, I am also taking the liberty to repair some 50 rods of this road drain, at an estimated cost of $100.00, half I suggest should be the responsibility of the road as the road benefits from this drain. I trust this meets with your approval, as this six inch tile will give all the drainage the school will ever need if put in proper working order.

Regarding Mr. Fred Stonefish the carpenter foreman I have no doubt as to his ability to read blue prints, and manage construction, I believe you will find a building when completed, as well constructed as any school.

Stuart Spence, Agency Superintendent.

Re: Moravian Day School

In connection with the construction of the Moravian Day School, I am and have run into some difficulty regarding wages paid.

Originally I had planned to employ Vester Jacobs throughout the job, and started him at 60¢ per hr., on the promise that I would pay him more if his services warranted it; he was very unsatisfied with this wage, and became disagreeable to work with. I could not see fit to raise his wages, of which he continually complained about, and when the cement walls was completed, I had a chance to let him go, and another labour that I had planned on quite when tobacco harvest started, but I was fortunate to be able to hire another good man, fairly experienced carpenter, at any rate willing, of which I am paying 85¢ per hr. therefore I have three good carpenters of which I am paying each 85¢ per hour, and one labour that I am paying 40¢ per hr.

When I planned on constructing this building with Indian labour I interviewed Albert Tobias an Indian of the Band, with the view of employing him, but he would never promise he would, for sure never the less, when the project was approved and we where ready to start he came on the job at 85¢ per hour, he is a good man, especially in cement work, and as good as the average carpenter, therefore to date we have made very good progress, and good workmanship. Mr. Tobias has informed me that unless he is paid $1.00 per hour he is going to quite the end of the week.

Mr. Fred Stonefish the carpenter foreman
Mr. Fred Stonefish, the approved carpenter foreman, is somewhat concerned over his pension allowance. An investigator from the Pension Department has been to the job to see him and warned him that he must not earn over $250.00 during the year or his pension allowance would be cut according to his earnings, with the results of this Mr. Stonefish has been threatening to quite. If I should lose both these men I would be at a loss to know what to do.

Mr. Tobias claims he can get $1.25 per hour. I don't doubt he can at this time. I have submitted tenders for the construction of a small house on the Reserve through welfare, one tender under the signature of Mr. Tobias. He advised me of his intentions, therefore I suggested he tender for this house rather than lose him altogether but I would much rather keep him on the school for another month at least.

As I write rafters over the main part of the building will be up ready for sheeting, and I would feel more at ease if the roof, siding, windows and outside doors were done.

Your views in the matter of this man's wages would be appreciated. I am of the opinion he is well worth the additional 15¢ per hour, this will include a power saw.

Stuart Spence,
Agency Superintendent.

Major MacKay:

Ottawa, October 6, 1949.

Director, 7-10-49.

Memorandum

Re: Moraviantown Indian Day School.

In Major MacKay's memorandum to you of September 12th last he requested that he be advised which of the two tenders for the electrical work at the above should be accepted and in this connection, we make the following comments.

The tenders received for this work are as follows:

(a) Mr. Melvin Grant, Highgate, Ontario.
   Wiring......................... $ 651.37
   Fixtures........................ 819.19
   Total......................... $1,470.56

(b) Mr. Norman Evans, Ridgetown, Ontario.
   Wiring......................... $ 502.00
   Fixtures........................ 678.59
   Total......................... $1,180.59

Mr. Grant's tender includes wiring and fixtures installed; Mr. Evans' tender does not include installation of lighting fixtures, which he states will be extra at the rate of $1.00 per man hour. Allowing approximately $100.00 for this charge, his installed price would amount to $1,281.59, which is the most favourable offer of the two submitted. We would suggest that the contract be awarded to Mr. Norman Evans.

Our electrical drawing was prepared as a standard plan for areas with a 60 cycle A.C. service, and we suggest that the Indian Affairs Branch request Mr. Evans to substitute "Holophane" lighting fixtures, Catalogue No. S-5540 with 200 watt lamps for the type "A" fluorescent units in the classrooms and 16" diameter R.L.M. standard dome porcelain enamelled steel reflector with outlet box canopy and 150 watt lamps for type "B" fluorescent fixtures in the basement. Two fixtures in the basement shall have pendant hood tapped for ½" conduit extension and mounted at the same level as the heating ducts.

The fixtures mentioned above, replacing those shown on our drawing, are less costly and the Indian Affairs Branch should request Mr. Evans to submit his revised price for supplying and installing these units.

We concur in wiring the school as outlined in option No. 1 in Mr. Evans' tender, which is in the amount of $502.00.

We are attaching herewith the tenders submitted with Major MacKay's memorandum for transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch.

Encl.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

MEMORANDUM

Hon. Mr. Meighen -

We have a very prosperous school on the Moravian Reserve in western Ontario, but there is no accommodation for the teacher, nor is there any boarding house available. The present teacher, who is giving good satisfaction, is now living in the ante-room of the school-house. The Indians have passed a resolution asking that a teacher's residence be built and that the necessary site be secured at the cost of $100.00. Mr. Abraham, our agricultural representative, prepared plans and specifications of which we approved and called for tenders from some firms in western Ontario. Only one responded, the Colin Reid Company of Rothwell, Ont., who offered to erect the building in accordance with the plans and specifications for $1150.00, which is $100.00 less than Mr. Abraham estimated.

We wish to commence the cement work without delay and I would ask your approval for the expenditure of the necessary amount from the capital funds of the band which amount to $111,178.99. I would add that this firm is a reputable one and has done considerable work for us in the past always to our satisfaction.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Mr. MacKenzie:

In reply to your letter No. 15-1-8, regarding the teacher's residence at the Moravian reserve, I beg to say that the residence that was built was erected to accommodate the school teacher, a Mr. Frank Joblin, who is a missionary school teacher and of course the building is not very satisfactory for a missionary. The Indians at the reserve and the council are not in favour of making any more improvements to the teacher's residence and the council passed a resolution stating that they will not provide any more funds for this purpose. They give as their reason that the missionary is a Methodist and that many of the people on the reserve do not belong to the Methodist church and therefore they as a band should not contribute towards the erection of buildings to accommodate the Methodist missionary.

I might say that there is a Methodist church on the Moravian reserve and quite a large number of the members of the Moravian band belong to this church. In view of this I would not recommend that any additional buildings, etc., be built at the school residence. Anything that can be done within reason to make Mr. Joblin more comfortable, such as papering the house and providing some shelves for the pantry, storm doors, etc., I believe should be done.

You have claimed that, if something can be made out of the mission property, the man who is doing the work ought to get it. The Department has ruled that the Society responsible for the missionary activity is entitled to such income. The Rev. Mr. Nethercott is paying to the church a fair rental for the privilege he enjoys and his relation to the church is solely that of a tenant and need not concern the active missionary.

The Department, as well as the Missionary Society, is desirous of retaining your services and I am explaining our position and ruling in some detail. Some time ago the band was approached with a view to disposing of the property in question and the placing of the proceeds into a new mission house to be erected near the council hall. This they were not willing to do. The Methodist Church and this Department are convinced that missionary teachers make better public servants when not engaged in farming activities.

Provision has been made in the Estimates for the coming fiscal year for alterations and additions to the property which you now occupy. I have today requested Mr. R. H. Abraham, our Agricultural Representative, to keep this matter in mind and to arrange for the work to be done at the earliest possible date.
I sincerely hope that these explanations will place you at ease in your important work and that in the future the Indian band and yourself will not have occasion to refer to this matter.

Dear Sir,

Are we too impatient in relation to the proposed improvements in connection with the teacherage here at Moraviantown? Rev. Thompson Ferrier told me in London last 26th Oct., that it had been arranged at the Dept. to build an addition to the house here. I entered into correspondence with the Dept., and with Mr. Abraham at Chatham, so that all the preliminaries could be gotten through with and the work started as soon as the weather permitted in the Spring.

I have letters from Mr. Russel T. Ferrier written Feb. 6 and Apr. 11th in which I was given to understand that the work would be done at the earliest possible date.

Up to the present there hasn't been a shovel full of earth turned nor a board drawn to the premises, and we are fairly sweltering in the heat in this little house, with no place to put the stove out.

The farmers are drawing their hay now, and if the stable were built, I could have the hay drawn right from the field. I will now have to pay nearly double the amount later on.

It must be that the delay is unavoidable but it does seem most unfortunate that it is so. Mr. Pope, who is expected to do the work, says they are rushed with work now, and could have been through with this job if it had been put through earlier. I hope the undertaking is not postponed for another year.

Yours sincerely,

Frank J. Dobbin.

Dear Sir,

We had expected that the teacherage here at Noraviantown would be equipped with caver-troughs last Fall, and that we would have the use of a cistern all winter, and I believe that the Dept planned for us to have these conveniences, but as yet nothing has been done.

The Agent, Mr. Beattie, of Highgate, gave the job for both cistern and caver-troughs to a fellow merchant of Highgate, Mr. Lambert, who has been promising to do the work ever since he was given the job, but always fails to fulfill his promises.

There was at least a couple of weeks last Fall before the ground was frozen, that he could easily have got the work done, and it would have meant so much to us if he only had. He even gave instructions for the hole to be dug for the cistern one Saturday and said he would be out on the Monday, but he got busy at something else and never came at all, and this spring the hole has been continually filling up with water and soaking through into the cellar, and now it is half filled again with earth and will require to be dug out again.

The only way we have of getting rain water is to catch what drips from the roof in vessels placed on the ground. The need for caver-troughs is particularly urgent because the only entrance to the cellar is from outside.

I have kept at the Agent and Mr. Lambert about it, reminding them verbally, by letter, and telephone; and your representative Mr. Abraham of Chatham, has called them both up on the telephone and been assured that the work would be done as soon as there was a fine day.

Dear Sir,

Replying to Dept. Letter #15-I-1, of the 17th inst., relative to exchange of Missionary Teacher at this agency;

I would say that Rev. C.W. Mo. Kenzie arrived on the 25th inst., and has taken charge of the work.

Was interviewing Mr. Mo. Kenzie yesterday, and feel quite certain that he is going to request some few changes in the residence;

He asked me to whom should he make application for alterations to be made to house, and I informed him that it might be well for him to take the matter up with the Church authorities and they could in turn arrange with Indian Department as to what should be done.

I know that the Council & Reserve feel that when the Mission Board have contributed nothing for the residence, stable, painting & repairs and fuel for residence, it is their turn to make any improvements required to the property at this date.

I might state, that it would seem a mistake had been made, by erecting a residence & stable of the kind that they did in 1923.

The residence is only 4 small rooms, one story, cellar under one room; when a cellar could have been placed under whole house and had the whole building another ½ or whole storey higher at very little extra cost.

The stable has a loft over all with hip roof, with sufficient room to house hay enough for two horses, and no occupant of residence has used the stable for else than a garage for car;

Half the expense would have erected a much better garage.

The residence is far too small for married man & family.
