Dear Sir,

Rev. C.W. McKenzie, the Missionary Teacher of my agency, has asked me to have new screen doors and windows placed on the teacherage, and gravel walks in front and to the garage; and repairs to cellar and drains etc;

And also, he has asked to have the garden plowed and manured and got ready for this season's crop;

In the garden plot at his residence, there is sufficient land for three or four family gardens, and the practice has been heretofore to have janitor or some member of Reserve, plow and prepare the lot have the teacher put in what small vegetables he requires, and the balance of land is planted to potatoes by the member and he and teacher get equal shares of the potatoes.

The past custom has given entire satisfaction to date, and it may be unwise to change it.

In regard to improvements & repairs to teacherage, the members of Council & Reserve are somewhat divided on this matter, as they feel that the Mission Board should be asked to assume some responsibility in this matter.

There are two Protestant churches on the Reserve, Anglican & the United Church, and only one school, the United Church receive all revenue from the mission farm which was granted by the Reserve years ago to the old Moravian Church, and although the Mission Board may be expending all said revenue on their church work of Reserve, yet the Anglicans get nothing and were originally just as much interested in the land granted as were others.

I state these facts to show the view taken by about ½ of Reserve.

Yours Obediently,

Nelson Stone, Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

Rev. C.E. Manning, Secretary of the United Church of Canada Board of Home Missions, Toronto, Ont., has written to me requesting that I arrange a Public Meeting of the Members of Reserve to meet him and others of his Board, to discuss the enlarging of the teacherage, and the moving of the old Mohawkian Church Building from the Mission Farm to a suitable site on Reserve, and repairing and remodelling the church building when moved.

He, Dr. Manning, asks me to act as chairman at such meeting, and states that he thinks the expenditure made in enlarging the teacherage should be paid from Band funds.

Now, I know the feeling on the Reserve is opposed to expending any of their funds for enlarging the teacherage; I also know that if we listen to the wants and whims of every teacher and missionary that comes to the Reserve, we would be making alterations continually to both school & Church property; each missionary teacher has his individual ideas as to equipment & buildings, and in some cases go so far as to insist on alterations being immediately made to conform with their ideas; and this would mean doing and undoing each year if we listen to them.

The members of Reserve are looking forward to one of their own being the Teacher of school, and they openly state that the teacher's residence as it is, satisfies them.

As there are two Churches on Reserve, Anglican & United Church, with about the same membership, I feel that as Agent, it is my duty to be neutral in church matters, and unless your Dept. insists on me doing so, I purpose to refuse to be mixed up in this proposition at all, and to notify Dr. Manning to this effect.

Please advise me at an early date as to what action I should take in this regard.

Form No. 101.
Dear Sir,

I have today received communication from Rev. C.W. McKenzie, Missionary Teacher of my agency, requesting permission to address the General Council of Moravian Band Monday next in regard to enlarging the teacherage;

Rev. McKenzie states in his letter that the expenditure should be made from Indian Educational Funds, and therefore the Indians would not oppose it;

In Dept. letter No. 15-1-8 of May 21/28, which was a reply to mine of May 17/28 dealing with a request by the late Dr. C.E. Manning of the Mission Board of United Church of Canada, similar in every respect to the present request of Rev. C.W. McKenzie; I was told to reply to Dr. Manning to the effect that matters of this kind, when they affect more than the congregation of the local church, should be taken up with Department of Indian Affairs.

Should I reply to Rev. C.W. McKenzie as to Dr. Manning? If so please advise me at once so that I can do so before Monday next.

As I view the matter, if expenditure is to be made entirely apart from Band funds, why deal with it in General Council?

Yours Obediently,

Nelson Stone, Indian Agent.

Ottawa, March 1, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, relative to the request of the teacher of the Moravian Indian Day School, viz.: permission to address the Indian Band in Council with reference to enlarging the teacher's residence. You should inform the Rev. Mr. McKenzie that, whereas any expenditure in this connection would have to be met by parliamentary appropriation, the matter should be brought to the attention of the Department. It is considered unnecessary and even unwise for a teacher to discuss with the Indian band in council expenditure from public funds without the permission of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Nelson Stone, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Highgate, Ont.
May 3, 1929.

MEMO FOR FILE:

I have discussed with Rev. Mr. Barner, Superintendent of Indian Missions of the United Church, the future of the work at the Moravian Indian Day School. In the event that the Rev. Mr. Wilding or another well qualified worker is appointed to this school, it may be necessary - depending on the number in the teacher's family - to enlarge the residence. I promised favourable consideration, in view of the fact that the Missionary Society is proposing to use during the next three or four years the rentals on the farm there for improvements to the buildings.
EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM REV ARTHUR BARNER,
WESLEY COLLEGE, WINNIPEG, MAN., dated June 7, 1929.

Indian Agent Stone will report in regard to the enlargement of the teachersage in due course. The way is opening for the making of improvements on the farm which we discussed and I shall be much obliged if the Department will authorize Mr. Stone to take oversight of these matters so that Mr. Leverton may have someone with whom to consult.
Rev. Arthur Barner, acting for Home Mission Board of United Church of Canada, has asked me to recommend to Indian Department enlargement and improvement to teacherage, this to be effected as soon as convenient after arrival of Rev. Wilding at Moraviantown. I hesitate to do this, as I feel the present plan combining the teaching and preaching to one individual is not in some respects very satisfactory, and may not be permanent, as the Anglicans are about as strong and numerous in membership as United Church. However, the present residence is far too small for any family, and is constructed in such a way that enlargement is very difficult. Cannot see what was the idea of erecting a house or stable like this one at that date, one storey small cottage with cellar under one corner, and too deep for proper drainage of cellar, one small bedroom. Had they put 2 storeys higher, bedroom upstairs, it would have cost but little more and now it would not require enlarging. The stable with loft above has never been used only as garage. Would like to be advised at an early date as to what would be your wish in these matters and I will try and carry out your wish.
Ottawa, July 17, 1929.

Sir:

I wish to refer to that portion of your letter of the 10th instant, which is relative to the teacher's residence at the Moravian Indian Day School. As it is too small for any family, I believe it advisable to consider an addition or an enlargement. The Department has promised the Board of Home Missions of the United Church that favourable consideration to enlarging this building will be given, provided they appoint a well qualified worker.

When the Rev. Mr. Wilding reports for duty, you will please discuss this question with him and let me have a recommendation as to how more room can be provided. You should estimate the cost of whatever addition is suggested.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Nelson Stone, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Dear Sir,

Replying to Department letter #15-1-8 of July 17/29, relative to enlarging teacher's residence;

I would say, that I consulted Rev. Wilding immediately on his arrival at this agency, and have since submitted the plans for enlarging & repairing to two reliable contractors for estimates;

We purpose extending the main building, east end, 12 ft., x 23 ft.; The present building is one story cottage roof, and impossible to add another story without destroying present roof and side walls. We also purpose erecting small woodshed at end of stable, as considerable wood has been removed each year after being delivered, and also if the wood was housed it is in much better condition for use than if exposed to rain & snow;

Will enclose copy of the two estimates received, and they will exhibit pretty well the nature of labor & material required for this work;

Chas. Hubbell estimate, $810.00, is $81.00 less than Warwick & Son, and includes one coat of good paint on present building, and painting woodshed, which are not included in the Warwick estimate;

Will expect an early reply, as it will be necessary to act promptly if this work is to be undertaken this Fall;

Yours Obediently,

Nelson Stone, Indian Agent;

Dear Sir:

Thank you,

I am, yours sincerely,

Harold Wadding.

Sir:

At a meeting of Mud Lake Band of Indians held at Lethbridge on the 3rd day of March 1899.

It was moved by George Tyler seconded by Alfred Copps that we wish it to be clearly understood that we have no fault to find with Miss Middleton in any way. But the wish of this Band was expressed to the Department in a resolution dated Feb. 24th asking that Mr. McLean be heard as teacher. The Department on the 6th Feb. approved of the appointment and authorized our agent Mr. Maclean to appoint Mr. McLean but for private reasons of his own, and because someone has gone behind the Band's back and told him something in "confidence" our agents ignore the approved wishes of the Band and protest to do as he pleases, and therefore as we have not been fairly dealt with in this matter, we cannot become responsible for the Teacher's salary.

Carried unanimously.

The Deputy Supt. General,

Re Mud Lake School.

This school has been in charge of an Indian, named Alfred McCue, since October, 1901, and during all that period he has failed to make a success of the school. The last report from the School Inspector shows that the school is without anything in the way of equipment. No requisition was received from the teacher since 1902, and it is solely due to his carelessness that this condition exists.

Mr. Inspector Ramsden, who visited the school lately, reports the same lack of equipment and says that he is sure that the method of teaching in this school is not along modern ideas.

The Indians are dissatisfied and careless about sending their children to school, but, if a qualified teacher, who is interested in his work, is given them, I am sure that a noticeable improvement would take place. There are over 25 children of school age on the reserve and it is too bad they should grow up in ignorance. They have a good school building and if the salary were raised a good teacher could be secured, and I would suggest that Mr. McCue's services be dispensed with after June 30, next, and the school reopened after the summer holidays with a new teacher.

Peterboro, Ont. July 9th, 1909.

Dear Dt. Sutherland,

Have just returned from looking over the Chemong work. On the reserve there are 190 Treaty Indians, besides about 30 others. They seem to be on the increase, there having been not more than 160 all told, twenty years ago.

They impress me as being a pretty good type of the race. Their homes seem fairly tidy. Was in two or three parlors that would do credit to anyone. Had as fine a dinner as King Edward need ask for. There are at least a dozen homes in which there is either piano or organ.

What they call the mission house is in fairly good condition, beautifully situated on the shore. Two acres for garden and a fine orchard. The Indian family occupying pays a nominal rental. He has a house of his own and as far as I could learn he would not object to the change if a missionary came. The house would be worth here $3,000, at least. The Indians bought it in view of missionary occupying it, and they would be glad if he were sent at once.

The new church is 30 x 45 brick with alcove additional for choir. It is well seated, lighted, heated (furnace) and as clean as a pin. It is the best looked after and neatest Indian Church I have seen. The old church, a frame is near by, in good condition and is used for S. School purposes. The school house and Council chamber is a fine substantial brick, two stories, and not much the worse of wear. Locked over the register, 28 names appear, the oldest 13 years of age. There are on the reserve not less than 40 to 45 who should be attending school.

I took the chief nd his brother, both reliable men, and Christians into my confidence, and told them what we would like to do. They felt sure that all would be delighted. The Department has practically dismissed the teacher, and the people have farewelled him so the way in that respect seems clear. Ours is the only service held on the reserve. The Methodist church, by common consent, has the right of way. Winter evenings they have a congregation of about 100 to 120. About 55 are members of our Church. They hold class and prayer meetings. Last year, they paid on minister's salary $50, and contributed to the Missionary Society $52.00. They have an active Ladies' Aid Society which raised about $50.00 last year the most of which was spent in caring for the sick.

It seems to me a perfectly clear case. If the necessary arrangements can be made with the Department, and the right man can be found, the change should be made.

Faithfully yours,

(Sgd.) Geo. W. Henderson.

Dear Sir,

I have just seen the Rev. Dr. Sutherland of the Methodist Missions, Toronto, and, on his advice, I am writing to you regarding a teacher's position in one of the Indian Schools now vacant. He himself will write. He informed me, by you on the subject in a day or two. I am a University graduate, a native of N.S.Wales, Australia, and of Scottish parents. I taught school in that country for...
several years. In 1905 I went to Hawaii to recruit my health, which is now perfect and has been since that year. There I taught a native school of over 20 pupils, and won the affectionate respect of scholars and parents.

I came to the U.S.A. in 1906, and have taught during three years in Nebraska, in rural schools, the last school being offered to me again for this year also. But as a Bishop's subject I preferred to come to Canada, which I did over two months ago (June or 1907), & I hold a First Grade Teaching Certificate of the
State Department of Nebraska... I have forwarded, to Dr. Sutherland, my references and testimonials, and given him details of my status and experience. I am in vigorous mental and bodily health, and am used to living and caring for myself in isolated places... I hate the Indian race, and in June-July 1907 made a tour of the Rosebud Reservation (South Dakota), with the Rev. Mr. Clark (Missionary), studying the school system, and addressing the Indians. I am a fluent and attractive speaker (I may say so without immodesty), and...

Dear Sir:

In compliance with your request of the 21st instant File No. 172,211-1 to visit Chemong Reserve at an early date, I may say I went there this week but unfortunately found Mr. Prosser away. I, however, made enquiries as to his conduct of the School and found the general opinion to be that he was not giving satisfaction. The Indians complained that he is not regular in his hours and has absented himself on different occasions, one for a half a day to attend a sale, school closed, one day in September last to show a trick bear at the Lindsay Fair and fifteen days during the hunting season of this Fall when his wife took charge of the School. They claim that he stated he had permission from the Department for this latter absence.

They also complained that he sleeps during School hours. One little girl of thirteen years of age whom I asked to give evidence stated that this happened a number of times and that he would put his feet on the desk and lay back in his chair. They also complained that he took little interest in preparing the scholars for the Christmas closing which has always been quite an event with these people and that he would not remain himself for the entertainment which took place on December 26th. He has had no clock since the Summer holidays, it having been broken and stored away in the Cupboard, they also claim that he has no watch. The School-room had a general untidy appearance, seats being piled up and in disorder. The attendance register is poorly and carelessly kept. I regret his absence during my visit and would much prefer to have had him present so that if he had any defense to offer for the
charges that were made against him, I would have been better able to have judged as to their accuracy. I may say, however, that there did not appear to be any ill-feeling towards him by any members of the Band, on the contrary they all said that he was a very good preacher but were just as unanimous that he was a very poor teacher. They claim that they do not need his services as a preacher as they are supplied each Sabbath Morning from the Selwyn Circuit.

I fear he is indifferent and lazy and that it would be in the best interests of the Department to allow him to devote all his time to the education of his trick bear.

I enclose you a resolution which was passed by the Band in my presence, which speaks for itself. If you deem it necessary for me to make another visit to the Reserve when Mr. Prosser is on duty, I will gladly do so.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of February 2nd file No. 172211 - 1, I have to report as follows:

I visited the Chemong Reserve and interviewed Mr. Prosser as well as having a meeting with the Band. I asked Mr. Prosser with reference to the statements that had been made at the former meeting and he emphatically denied having been irregular in opening and closing the school. He admitted being absent one half day without leave when Mrs. Prosser took charge. He also states that the charge made against him of sleeping during school hours is of a trivial nature but did not deny that he might have dozed on one or two occasions. I enclose a statement he gave me signed by a number of the larger scholars with reference to this matter. As school was in session when I arrived, I took the opportunity of asking the scholars present which numbered twelve if any of them had ever seen him asleep during school hours and they all answered in the negative.

He claims he loses none of the school time in the attention he bestows upon his trained bear. He states he is sorry he did not remain for the entertainment at Christmas time as he believes that fact considerably agitated the Indians. He states that the young girl who gave some testimony against him at the last investigation interfered with the discipline of the school so much so as to tell a scholar that they had read long enough and when he did not agree with her, she left the school and has not returned since.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6148, File 414-1, part 1)
The Band was not nearly so much of one mind as to Mr. Prosser's conduct at the school on this visit as on my former visit, but they were in favor of having a certificated teacher and voted for this seventeen to ten. I may say that I am always favored getting as good teachers as possible but pointed out to the Band the difficulty the Department was experiencing in getting qualified teachers to remain for any length of time on some of the different Reserves. Some of the members of the Band were of the opinion that Mr. Prosser had never had a fair chance as the Council had passed a resolution requiring him to order no further supplies from the Department for the children, but that the parents of the children should be required to furnish all necessary school books. This I may say in my opinion does not work out well and causes a shortage of the necessary articles for the carrying on of the school.

Mr. Prosser was preceded by Mr. Cork who was an exceptionally good teacher and for this reason it would be more difficult for anyone to give the same satisfaction as might otherwise obtain. The Band were high in their praises of Mr. Cork, in fact a great deal higher than when Mr. Cork was in actual occupation of the position for at that time some of them complained to me and said that he was too old and desired his removal.

I may say that the school had a better appearance than on my last visit. The register was better kept and the school room tidy. There should however be a clock in operation in the schoolroom. Some of the members of the Band quite freely expressed their opinion that Mr. Prosser was doing much better since my last visit. Mr. Prosser is of the opinion tha School Inspector Broderick who visited
the school in December 1910 would commend his work.

The Band is aware of the fact that the Department intends allowing Mr. Prosser to remain at least until the Summer holidays, by that time the Indians may be in a different frame of mind.

Mr. Prosser can do well if he applies himself and I think the Department should write him and tell him he is on trial for the last time and that it is expected that he will do his very best to increase the attendance by persuading/to interest the children and by working agreeably as possible with the Council and members of the Band. I would also ask him for a report as to the equipment of the school as in my opinion the resolution passed by the Council favoring the parents supplying the books to the children is a mistake.

Yours obedient servant,

Dear Brother:

A Conference on Indian Work is to be held at Mt. Elgin Institute, Muncey, Ont., beginning on the evening of the twenty-third day of this month. This is a Conference held by the order of and under the direction of the General Board of Missions, with a view to making as thorough a study as possible of the Indian Work. It is, therefore, important that each member of the Commission on Indian Work as well as each worker engaged in Indian Work should be present. Such topics as the following will be presented and it is hoped that each member of the Conference will come prepared to offer some contribution to the discussion:

"How to make the Indian a good Citizen"
"Remnants of Paganism"
"Why should we educate the Indian"
"Indian home life"
"How far can Indian Missions be made self-supporting"
"Possible co-operation between White Work and Indian Missions"

It is also expected that each member of the Conference engaged in Indian Work will come prepared to give a report of his Mission, including the number of Indians under his care, the present conditions under which he is carrying on his work, adequacy of equipment and the future prospects of his work.

The Board undertakes to meet the travelling expenses of the delegates to the Conference, that is, of each missionary or missionary teacher and member of the Commission on Indian Work. It cannot undertake to provide for the expenses of the wives of any of the delegates, neither can entertainment be provided for any but the members of the Conference owing to the limited accommodation at Mount Elgin Institute.
It is also expected that the delegates will take advantage of the holiday rates which run from the 23rd to the 26th. Owing to the importance of the work it is thought that ample time should be allowed for the fullest discussion. The programme is being planned to cover the evening of the 23rd and the whole of the 24th and 25th. Muncey is on the Michigan Central Railroad, about thirteen miles East of St. Thomas. Delegates on enquiry at their local stations will be able to receive information as to routes and trains.

Trusting that this Conference may result in great good for the work at large, I am,

Yours sincerely,

Sir,

With reference to the Mixed Lake School, I am to say that the children are not making the progress that they should. They are not interested in their studies or in their play. They are as bright as any children in the country, and yet they do not get on as they should.

The formation of the trouble, I would say, lay in the system followed in employing the teacher. There is a teacher recommended by the Mission Board as teacher and preacher. The Department engages him on three-year terms. He is placed in a village to teach where the parents have no control over him whatever. They have absolutely no say in the matter; consequently, they are indifferent. They are not interested. The school is visited once a month by the agent who makes a report, but for anything further, he has no authority. The teacher may refuse to follow his instructions—and by the way does. The school is visited once a year by an inspector who reports excellent work being done. An inspector by the way who stated in a convention during the past year, that Indian children had not the capacity for learning that white children had—He had a lively opposition in Miss M.E. Shurp of St. James' School. I am stating conditions as I find them. I am well aware that the difficulties are not easily overcome, but it would be worth while trying.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

At a meeting of the Council of Chemong Band it was resolved that I should be dismissed from being Teacher. The causes that have led to this resolution, I find, are mainly not connected with the school. The parents who have sent their children with even fair regularity are anxious to have me retained. Some who have failed to send their children and whom I have tried to compel to do so vote to have me dismissed; the mover of the resolution has three little girls all over school age who have never been sent an hour to school, who wander almost as wild as Indians ever were. Others object to the School garden. Another objection was that I do not visit the sick; their Local Preacher told me more than a year ago that he had been appointed to do that as he could use their own language. Some are offended because I will not loan money to them. Also, I send to the city for supplies as I find prices at the village store exorbitant, this store is conducted by the Chief and his father.

These causes are all petty and unworthy. I have striven ever since I came here for the welfare of the Indians. I gladly invite an unbiased and efficient inspection of my work. Unfortunately the Agent is not capable of doing this.

Will you kindly let me know if the Band has power to dismiss the Teacher? If so what warning must be given?

Also, must I leave the house and garden at this time of year? If so can I claim remuneration for the same?

If I have to leave at the close of this term can I claim salary in proportion of the number of days taught to the number of teaching days, as can be done in other schools?

Will you kindly give these questions your consideration and answer me at your earliest opportunity, by return mail if possible?

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of official letter of the Department No. 17221/1 dated Aug. 27th, 1916 regarding the resignation of Mr. Buffam teacher of Chimooy School. I wish to say that I am very much pleased that he has resigned. Mr. Buffam has not been a success as a teacher. I sincerely hope his successor will take a greater interest in the children.

I note that you have requested the Secretary of the Methodist Missionary Society to secure a qualified teacher. I must say that I have grave doubts about the wisdom of that system. I think if the Department would engage the teacher through their own supervision or through a school board of the members of the Band with assistance of the agent or some one who is directly interested and would have direct supervision then that there would be better results. I have had a great deal of worry over this school. For the last year there has been an agitation in the Band to put the teacher away. The parents take a lively interest in the education of their children, and it was discouraging to see them make so little progress.

Mr. Buffam is well qualified but not adapted.

Your obedient servant,

REPORT ON MUD LAKE RESERVE.

R. H. Abraham, B. S. A.

SCHOOL FAIR.

The school fair held at Chemung school was, considering the fact that it was the first fair of any kind ever held on that reserve, a decided success. All the produce was grown by school pupils from seed supplied through the Indian Agent, from your Dept. Exhibits were made of corn, beets, onions, pumpkins, squash, canned fruit, peas, beans, carrots, parsnips, tomatoes, apples, drawing, writing, etc.

There was a lack of system about the fair that can be improved next year.

(1) The children should know in the spring what they can win prizes for.

(2) They should know what an exhibit should consist of.

(3) They should have the fair organized; a president, vice-president, sec.-treas., and a committee should be appointed from the school children. This should be done in the spring of the year.

For next year we can make arrangements to have these things done at the proper time.

Dear Sir:

- Re Chemong Indian School -

A careful reading of my letter of December 8th on this matter shows that I made no recommendation for a change of teacher. My last communication put the Department in possession of the information which had come to me concerning conditions at Chemong, but made no suggestion that dismissing the teacher would provide a solution for the whole matter. Dear Sir:

I desire however to lay before you a number of complaints that have been made regarding trouble at the Chemong Indian Reserve for some time past on account of the bad management.

In the first place Chief Dan Whetung was elected chief on 16th October 1913 for three years till October 1916.

Last spring he notified us he had been re-elected although we did not get notice to attend the meeting, only his own voters, and the election should not have been held then and he was not properly re-elected.

When the teacher was appointed the Chief informed her that there was no Mission house in the Village (which was untrue) and said he had a house of his own he rented to school teachers at $8.00 per month. The Chief wanted the Mission House for himself, and he told people he was going to live in it. He objected to the Teacher having a pump and had it taken out.

He quarreled with the Teacher and assaulted her husband, and was fined for so doing by the Police Magistrate and then out of spite closed the school and kept the key of the school. Parents are compelled to send their children to school, but were not allowed to do so on account of the action of the chief.

The Teacher is well qualified and has had fourteen year's experience, and no fault can be found with her, but the Inspector required certain improvements which the Chief refused, and Rev. Mr. Arnup wrote that the Inspector would not go to the Village again till a change was made there.

I applied for the privilege to cut wood at the public reserve for those who have no wood lots, and was refused while the supporters of the Chief were allowed to cut wood there and nothing was done to them, and the Indian agent did not object.
so far as we knew. The agent does not treat us fairly. He has secrets with the Chief and acts without consulting the band and allows the Chief to act without consulting the band.

The Indian Act (Section 96) provides that the Chief may be deposed for dishonesty, intemperance, immorality or incompetency by the Governor in Council.

The Chief was guilty of intemperance. He was seen drunk in the Little Windsor Hotel in Peterboro. He was seen one Saturday night last summer taking his auto car near the Mission House and the next day several of the men were seen staggering around drunk.

He was also guilty of bribery and threatening to force people to sign a petition to dismiss the school teacher, and telling them if they refused they would be refused credit at the store owned by him and his father.

I have proof for all the above, and regret I was not informed when your officer went to the Reserve yesterday so that I could be there to prove my statements to him. I would ask to have the present Chief deposed.

Thanking you for your courtesy in the past,

I am

Yours truly,

[Signature]

I beg to report that I have visited the Chemong school and made inquiries as to the teacher with the following results.

I first visited the school, preferring to hear the teacher's side of the trouble before listening to the Indians. I found the school in session but a very small attendance. Mrs. Haines informed me that she understood that the children not at school were being kept at home by their parents. Asked as to their reasons for keeping children away from school, she told me that she thought Chief Dan Whetung to blame for the parents' actions. She also stated that the Chief had locked the school up and that she was unable to re-open it at the proper time after the New Year. In endeavoring to find out what cause, if any, the Chief had for opposing the teacher I had to listen to a great deal of church and "Ladies Aid" gossip which appears to have been largely the cause of the present condition of ill-feeling between the teacher and some of the Indians. Unfortunately, Mrs. Haines appears to have got herself mixed up in church troubles and has not been as careful as she might have been in her remarks about certain of the ladies of the church. The climax of the trouble seems to have been reached when the teacher wrote the word "whore" on the blackboard. There are various versions as to what took place and what was said in connection with the meaning of the word. In making her explanation of the affair, Mrs. Haines contradicted the version she gave in her letter to the Department. She stated to me that Daisy Whetung's name was not mentioned at the time by any one in the school. One of the school boys told me that he heard her connect Daisy Whetung's name with the meaning of the word. Mrs. Haines, in her letter to the Department, states that one of the school children
mentioned the name. Whether or not Mrs. Haines mentioned this person's name in connection with the word does not appear to me to be material, especially after hearing all she had to say about Miss Whetung. It was plainly evident from Mrs. Haines' remarks that, no matter what she may have said, she certainly believes Miss Whetung to be immoral. But apart from this it would appear that the writing of such a word on the board in front of a class of children was very unwise. The result has been that the majority of the Indians resent such conduct on the part of the teacher and refuse to send their children to school. I regret to have to say that Mrs. Haines showed a rather vindictive spirit in her remarks and I could plainly see that to leave her in charge of the school would be useless. However good a teacher she may be, she has spoiled her usefulness so far as Chemong is concerned.

In taking the matter up with the Indians, I found that their chief cause of complaint was the afore-mentioned instance in connection with Miss Whetung. I also ascertained that a very large majority of the Indians were against her and that they claimed to be taking such a stand independently and not for the sake of supporting the Chief. I also found that the Indians were willing to accept a new teacher who was brought by the Agent. I requested them to leave the matter in the hands of the Department and that it would be dealt with, but did not state what action would be taken. They asked that they be advised as to what conclusion was reached and I told them that they would probably hear through their Agent as soon as anything was decided upon. I beg to recommend that another teacher be secured for the Chemong school and that Mrs. Haines be given two months notice of the change.

Your obedient servant,

Re Chemong School.

Yours of recent date is to hand, announcing the decision of the Department to effect a change of teachers at this point on March 31st next.

The General Secretary and myself concur in the view that a situation has arisen at Chemong which so seriously discounts the usefulness of the present teachers, Mrs. W. J. Hanes, as to make a change of teachers desirable.

Before entering into direct negotiations with another teacher we should be very glad to learn what steps the Department proposes to take in order to make the position of the teacher at Chemong reasonably secure against unwarranted interference on the part of Chief Whetung, the Chief's father, and other members of their family. This request is based on information already communicated to the Department by correspondence or in personal conversation.

I beg to refer to the evidence furnished (1) by the teacher, (2) by the constable, (3) by the Public School Inspector, Mr. G. E. Broderick, of Lindsay, regarding earlier difficulties. You will recall the statements concerning threats and intimidation directed against both Mr. and Mrs. Hanes, the police court conviction for assault, the locking of the
school-house door, which indicate not merely an attitude of personal antagonism to the present teacher but an assumption of authority and a disregard of legal rights which, if persisted in, could not fail to affect injuriously the position and efficiency of any teacher who might be appointed. We have reason to fear that the removal of Mrs. Hanes, if unaccompanied by any expression in regard to the methods above referred to, would seem to strengthen the position of this family in their attitude towards the school.

This letter is in no sense intended as a criticism of the attitude or action of the Department to date, which in its fairness and moderation has earned our support as already expressed. In real anxiety for the future, however, we desire to direct this inquiry for information regarding further action.

Methodist Missionary and His Wife Were Defended in an Action

For some time past an attempt has been made to have vacated the premises occupied by Mr. W. J. Haines and his wife at the Chemong village. A STATEMENT

Mr. Gordon makes the following statement in connection with the case:

The Methodist Missionary and his wife, who is a teacher, were asked by Chief Daniel Whetang when they intended to leave, and Indian Agent McCannus told them they could find this was notice to vacate and he issued warrants for the arrest of the woman and her husband, and sent an Indian from the Reserve to make the arrest. If either of these parties had been arrested off the Reserve the arrest would not have been legal, as the Indian Agent had no power to issue a warrant for an arrest outside the Reserve. He has gathered his own and few followers around him. They hold their own council meetings and do not attend the regular council which is held once a month, and which the members can attend and have any matter fairly and squarely discussed and settled according to the wishes of the people. Mr. Knott who is not an actual member of this band is one of the main supporters of Joe Whiting. He goes from house to house with all kinds of untrue stories spreading discontent among the people and making trouble in many homes. Joe Whiting and some Knott families imagine and spread impossible reports, such as this, that we want to get mission house and change it into a boarding house that we are trying to induce Potts, a white man who married one of the ladies here, to live here as resident etc. These reports are entirely imaginary and untrue.

That Joe Whiting be made to understand that he is not recognized.

To the Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Gentlemen,

The Mud Lake Indian Day School has been without a teacher since the beginning of the school year and has been without a teacher of any qualifications for a great number of years and as the results I regret to say not one single child has accomplished much as to pass the examination for entrance to high school in the last five or so years.

I understand that the Government is spending money to advance the Indians why not spend it in this section? We are willing to pay more for a qualified teacher and no other kind will do. We have from 15-25 children school age and what is the average? It is because the Indians are discouraged with such lack of school teachers sent to our Reserve—

Previously the mission Board and Ind. Dept. has been employing
But I strongly suggest that the Ind. agent be authorized that he advertise in the local paper & posterboard and secure a good teacher which he is most capable of doing.

Hoping this will be met with your approval and that a qualified teacher is secured.

I had to go away from my Reservation to get what little education I have and I am sending one child away from home now to be taught by a qualified teacher is this going to be continued? I hope not. I hope that there will be a different system of securing a teacher.

Dear Sir:

I visited the Indians at Chemong, or Mud Lake, last week and discussed with them the question of a missionary-teacher for that point. You will remember that I mentioned the name of Mr. Joblin as a likely man to take up that work. I find that there is local objection to Mr. Joblin—largely because of his domestic relations with the people at Alnwick, several of which tribe are married among the Indians at Chemong. I think, therefore, we shall have to drop that name and try to find someone else.

I discovered that there is a large attendance of children at the School there, and the people think that one teacher is overburdened with the task. There are at the present time twenty-eight children in the primary class, and an average attendance of forty in the entire School. They suggest that next year two teachers be appointed; that the teacher in the senior room be a man and that he act as missionary-teacher. I pass this on for your information, and you will use your own judgment when the returns for the year in connection with the School come in.

I received a notice from Mr. W.M. Eastwood, Indian Agent, Mud Lake, and Rice Lake, that my services would not be required after Oct. 1st.

I cannot understand why, unless that some one has been reporting things that are absolutely one-sided and I feel fairly sure that such has been done.

I received your letter re Inspector Downey's report. As far as it is possible I have given individual
teaching. As far as possible,
the classes is concerned
it was done for the sake
of the children—not mine.
There was no foundation
to work on—and I found
the senior 15 not one whit
ahead of the junior as
regards any one subject.
By putting them together
as very many teachers do,
I had more time to give longer
and more frequent lessons,
such as are extremely nec-
essary here.

The same is true of the
two thirds. The class just
promoted from the junior
room was ahead of the
junior in ground work
in arithmetic.

If Mr. Downey had given
me a chance to really ex-
plain the situation,
Instead of taking it for granted that I must be a failure, the world, I verily believe, have sent me a different report.

As for the A.T. class which I was to take from the other room to lessen the pressure of numbers there, I had every intention of taking them when I had the other classes advanced enough so that they would take less time. They were taken last week 2 November. I knew Miss Long could at first do more for them than I could, so she could and did combine her II & I Classes in Language & Geography. Now it is different; Classes,
though by no means up
to standard in every-
thing, do know some-
thing well, however,
more briskly are inter-
ested, and History lessons
are no longer a trial,
are more better lessons
too, but a time of real interest.
I have always had the
reputation of being a
teacher who never neglects
the slow pupils, and
though I've had Entrance
Classes nearly every
year, have not had a
pupil fail for fifteen
years, and then it was
my first year in a
new school.

There is much immorality
here, and help is greatly
needed in Church & Sunday
school. I have a large class in the latter—young people and some older ones. While I was away the Sunday there was no Sunday School as there was no one to take my class. I have begun a club for my big school boys, and it is to help them grow square—slow work and discouraging at times it must be. But I love boys' work.

I don't dance, play cards, etc., but I have not once in any way interfered with those who do, nor mentioned such pleasures in O.S. or day School. I don't believe "trades" are the best means of fighting whiskey, tobacco, and immorality, and almost every girl 17 fourteen and
over smokes cigarettes more or less, and some of my boys are steeped in them.

Why should my children and the people generally be robbed of the only one in the whole Reserve that is quietly trying to help them to live decent Christian lives and on the whole really enjoying the work too?

Besides, anything I can do outside of school work, is not detracting from the success of the school work but rather aiding it. Such work does not require as much time as addresses, cards, and boyfriends.

I think almost every one who saw the school...
Concert we put on this year says it was the evergreen here. My room gave a cantata taking nearly an hour; clean interesting full of the real spirit of Christmas. The children love singing and the sprightliness of the dialogue part was a surprise to many.

Mr. Whiting may be "a very progressive Indian," but he & his family do not try to help in uplift in any way.

I know I have the sympathy of the better class here who do want to see their children get on. It is unfair to the Entrance particularly, who all failed dismally last year, to give them a new teacher just now.

We do need here a teacher's house badly.

I need money, too.
after all, that only
self myself & those
dependent on me God
for every one perhaps
the greatest blessing one
can have, almost per-
fect health combined
with an intense love for
the great outdoors, and
I use both, (the combination,
I mean) in all my
work.

I'd surely be glad if
you would reconsider
your decree, and if
I do not make for
by June, then send
in the ultimatum.

Yours sincerely,

Margaret Gardiner.
Principal -
Mad Lake Indian
Day School.

One interested in Christian work sent me a surprise gift of fifteen lovely Bibles two weeks ago. The children, several of them, both boys and girls, are memorizing the Commandments and a goodly number of Bible verses in order to win a Bible.

I was in a home visiting a sick girl one day last week. I told of the news from the Dept. The next day, I was sent a note asking me to go to the home of one
To the Indians and bring my letter. I did so. We met the chief on there and I talked for a short time, then he said he would get up a petition as several had that day told him they would sign one. I have not heard since what they did, or whether they have done anything, as I cannot make myself ask questions like that. I'd never make a politician - couldn't canvass votes.

I do think, however, that the people ought to be allowed to speak sometimes. Otherwise how shall they ever get any sense of responsibility.

Would not the Government Inspector - who comes here once a year - I think (I've never met him)
Come now and do an act of simple justice by investigating this matter at once?

I feel my responsibility for the welfare of these children so much, and I like them and the work so well, and have found such genuine friendliness among the older people—parents especially—that I am loath to give up the work here.

The night I received the fatal (?) message from Mr. Eastwood I wrote voicing my suspicions and a few opinions, trusting to his honour not to divulge them, at least some of them, without due consideration. But I surely said nothing thought to be untrue.

I know heads of Departments are busy, and often callous too, but I'm hoping you are not the latter, and that you will read this thoughtfully. It has been written after much thought and prayer.

Yours, M. Gardiner

Dear Mr. Eastwood,

Recently you asked me to note down and send to you facts regarding the Ontario plan for training handicapped children in rural areas. I am glad to summarize here information I have gathered.

Ontario now has a fully organized system of educating such children without removing them from their home and school environment. The school is surveyed by Provincial officials who diagnose the needs of the children. Units of special training are then prescribed according to the child's needs. With the help of these units, the local teacher can carry on.

The units are of several kinds, but those of particular interest here would be—

(a) Opportunity Units, for pupils who are unusually backward in any overall subject.

(b) Sight-saving Units, for children whose eyes are defective.

I quite believe that I am justified in stating that Opportunity Units would be of even greater value to our Indian School than to the average "white" school. Miss Long & Mr. Rome, with long experience here, heartily agree.

I mention the sight-saving unit because of the frequent occurrence of trachoma among the Indians. There are two cases under treatment in the school at present, and while I am told that they stand in little danger, it is conceivable that the sight-saving units might be of value at some future time.

Cape Lake,
Oct. 13, 1938.
A word on the nature of the training given to backward children might not be out of place. The emphasis is placed on the fundamentals: reading, writing, spelling, arithmetic. Special direct teaching methods & materials are employed. After 18 years, an attempt is made to teach some manual crafts sewing, knitting, wood carving, seed work, in simple forms, give the child skills which enable him to hold up his head among the children who are learning more rapidly than he in literary fields.

Regulations for Ontario state that the teacher should hold an Auxiliary Class certificate. If not, however, temporary certificates may be issued to suitable teachers for 1 year. I may state here that I am prepared to take the course in Auxiliary work this summer, if we get cooperation from the Dominion. I feel that a knowledge of Auxiliary methods would be of more value to a teacher of Indians than any other single summer course.

The only information regarding cost of these units which I could locate was in an article by Dr. Amoss, Can. Sch. Journal, Feb., 1936. In speaking of cost, he says "It may be noted that the average cost of each training unit last year was under $3.00." Although this seems unreasonably low, the context seems to indicate that $3.00 was the actual total cost per unit.

Dr. Amoss, Inspector of Auxiliary Classes, Dep. of Education, Toronto, is in charge of the work.
Since I have a strong personal desire to see these units put into operation here, I hope you will bear with me if I set down what are really opinions. I feel that the advantages of using this work would be these—

First, to the pupils—handicapped—

They would be thoroughly trained in the three "R's."

They would be mentally much healthier; their self-respect retained, their spirit unbroken by a continual feeling sense of inferiority. This same feeling of inferiority is at the root of much actual mental illness occurring in later life.

Genuine interest in schoolwork should cut down truancy, very common in this type pupil.

Happily occupied, he no longer should be furnishing a continual entertainment for the rest of the school.

Renewed interest in schoolwork would give the teacher a chance to inculcate sensible health and living habits.

Second, to the remaining members of the class—

More advanced teaching methods could be used. More work done by class, less by teacher, in learning new facts, etc.

The drag of the dull pupil would be removed.

This would mean the fuller exploration of new fields uncovered in schoolwork, the introduction of interesting topics otherwise untouched; in short, the covering a wider & richer course than the teacher, faced with the need of constantly drilling the slow scholar, could possibly have covered before.

Class standards would be higher. The clever child would no longer have the dull pupil as a foil.
I might add a third division—the benefits to the community. In the work of training the Indians to take a place in the outside world, the school—I'd think—is the most powerful factor. Increasing the school's efficiency would seem to be the apparent way to bring the end of Indian isolation a lot closer. And I believe that the introduction of this system of auxiliary training would increase the efficiency of our schools materially.

One point I might raise in closing: these units should make it possible, in two-teacher schools, to place the great lumps of boys stagnating in primary grades under the care of the man teacher. These big boys present a much simpler disciplinary problem to a man than to a woman.

I hope, Mr. Eastwood, that this report is satisfactory; and that you will forgive what may seem unwarranted verbosity in spots. I have come to feel strongly on these spots. I hope my inexperience has not led me astray.

Sincerely,

Stuart Mackey.

Re: File 25-1-1(WT1) dated March 20th,

In an effort to secure the services of a teacher for the junior classroom of the Mud Lake Indian School, to replace Miss Shirley Hamilton who resigned, I find that the provincial regulations in regard to granting teachers certificates places an obstacle in the way of securing the services of a graduate teacher from the Normal School.

Requirements for the granting of a certificate include the condition that a teacher must teach one year following his or her graduation from Normal School in a school receiving a Provincial grant and although I have not seen a certificate, I believe it is typed across the face of the certificate. I have discussed this with Mr. Leo W. Copp, principal of the local Normal School, and he has been kind enough to communicate with the Provincial Department of Education and in his correspondence with his Department, confirmation of this has been received and it is pointed out that an Indian Day School is not regarded as the necessary qualifying experience.

If our interpretation of this regulation is correct, it will be difficult to get the services of Miss Phylis Davidson, who I hope to secure for the 15th of May.

I am now in touch with Mr. K. O. Birkin, inspector for East Peterborough, concerning the possibility of securing one of two teachers now available. He is to advise me as to their qualifications and I hope to receive word from him in a few days. Both these prospective teachers have been teaching for some time.

In the meanwhile the junior classroom, with an enrolment of forty-two pupils, has been out on an enforced holiday. I am hopeful of getting someone to take charge this week even on a temporary basis, regardless of their qualifications.

P.P.Z. Oshawa, Ont.,
Feb. 29th, 1932.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

I cannot remember whether I gave you the above address the day you were at Curve Lake, or left you with the other address, McKellar, only. I have not yet received my salary cheque for January, and have been wondering if it might have been sent and delayed somewhere.

I am at present with a sister-in-law near Oshawa who has to make up a big payment on her farm this week. With that cheque I can manage to give her £250 to help out so am hoping it will come along soon if possible. I left address at Mr. Eastwood's office where I went twice in a vain endeavour to see him about something else.

My memories of Curve Lake cannot fail to
be happy ones, for the kindness of the people was truly wonderful—a big surprise tea-party in the hall the last night I was there, gifts—quill boxes from your mother when I called to say good bye.

I thought you'd be what you said—"you'll leave in a Christian spirit," but I'm British and Irish, and did not think it contrary to a Christian spirit to try to say a few words to Dan Whiting when paying my board, just before I left (not about board), intending to ask him to shake hands then, as I do want some day to visit Curve Lake, if only for an hour or two, and want to feel free to enter Dan's home too. It was all a mistake, however, as I should have known after my experience over the seats "question." Hope I'll never again see such a look of malicious hate and triumph on any man's face as was on his.

I do thank you sincerely for having come to Curve Lake, and I know all will be for
the best.

I have not forgotten that you said you would hereafter take into consideration when choosing teachers, the fact that some reserves need teachers who can lead in church and Sunday School work. It will mean much.

I have never found people who were so grateful for little visits; nor who responded more readily to sympathy with their joys (they are Jews) and cares and sorrows. Indians are supposed to be stoical but I saw tears in the eyes of even two or three men when I said good-bye, though I shed none myself (didn't dare).

Pardon this long letter, and believe me when I say I am glad I met you, and glad that you are the Superintendent of Indian Education.

Yours sincerely,

Margaret Gardner
Miss Gardiner - RR No 2
Salary for January 95.00

Miss Gardiner relinquished duties as of 8 January 1932

BRICK WORK.

All walls will be finished, and all walls and chimneys built with the finest quality of stock brick. Bricks must be uniform, sized off a uniform deep red color, laid up about 1/2" from the meeting and attached in full of mortar to sheathing every course. The work must be neatly and carefully beaded with red mortar colored with oxide of iron, the heading must be level and uniform and well sunk in brickwork on completion. Clean joint and fill all holes. The mortar is to be composed of French Georgetown lime and clean sharp acid well mixed, in all cases brick work full of mortar and clean will stand weather. To the Hon. Dept. of Ind. Affairs
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

We the Mud Lake Band of Indians have been trying to find out when Mr. Wilson is going to finish the second contract by our agent Mr. McFarlane and as we cannot get any real satisfaction from him we therefore write to you.

The resolution past by our band here was to pay Mr. Wilson $500.00 to furnish all the necessary of the combined building, that is the seating of the council chamber, with long seats and chairs for the committee room. Of course we have seats in the present school which will do if repaired a little to put in the new school along with about 4 (four) new larger ones for larger pupils and lamps for the council chamber. This room will also be used for entertainments and the seats must be got at once as the combined building will be open sometime next month by having tea-meeting and concert.

We received the estimates from Mr. McFarlane which Mr. Wilson the contractor made out.

It is a shame how he has let down for price. Why! The closets and fencing which
he has $50.00 for can all be done buying the stuff and erecting it for about $10.00 or $20.00. The fence is only about 8 or 9 feet long from the closest church fence as shown here. Why this is a shameful work, as we Indians have very little money and have no money to spend on extravagantly. We don't mind paying for a thing what its worth, but when it goes as far beyond the place. Of course we have very little idea of what a furnace is worth, but he has furnished $70.00 and $50.00 for brick and labor, which we think is steep enough, and cutting holes for furnaces $25.00 a place for maps $25.00.

All we are asking is to have our combined building furnished with all the accessories needed both inside & outside just as our resolution stated. When we paid our resolution on 5th Nov. 1901. We stated to give Mr. Wilson $500.00 to furnish all the necessaries of the combined building both inside & outside and the seats for the council chamber, are the things most needed, and immediately. We do hope he has not received the $500.00 yet until he completes his contract. We complained with the agent early to see that the second contract is done right and properly.
We also told Mr. McFarlane agent, and Mr. Blackwell
the architect that so much will be taken out of
the first contract as it was not fulfilled. The lack
of mortar on the roof was not put on and also on
between the brick wall and the frame wall, and the
chimney is 6 feet at the bottom and only 5 brick wide
at the top which is a very bad chimney to carry off
the smoke. We hope that this work carried out and
is settled. Likely you know of the estimates of
the second contract but I will just copy which
we received from our agent.

Furnace ... $170.00
Closets ... $150.00
Placing seats/decks ... $5.00
Brick for furnace/bricks ... $50.00
Cutting holes etc. for pipes ... $25.00
Case for maps ... $25.00
Concrete for furnace bottom
filling in holes for furnace ... $50.00

Total ... $505.00

We are satisfied with the rest of the building except the
above statement. Wishing to give us an early reply
and write direct to us for once, as this is very
important and no delay, for the new building will soon
be opened, and seats are wanted.

Daniel Whiting, Jr. Secretary. Joseph Brown Chief

Sir,

At a meeting of Mudlake Band of Indians held Dec. 26th, 1901.

It was moved by Alfred McEwan seconded by James McEwan that in reply to No. 13211 the letter of Dec. 1st, Mr. Lean, Esq., of the 21st inst., in which it is stated that agent McFarlane informed the Department that our Band approved the tender of T.J. Wilson for "finishing and furnishing the combined council and school house."

We beg to say the tender of T.J. Wilson was never placed before us. We never saw it and it was never read to us, but agent McFarlane was present at our council meeting on Nov. 5th and he told us that T.J. Wilson's tender was to finish and furnish the combined school and council house with seats and desks, lights, lamp case and furnace and to build the necessary closets and fence outside for $500.00.

And on the strength of agent McFarlane's statement of the tender, as we had nothing else to go by, and for the things and work stated by him we passed the resolution referred to, as requested by a letter from the Department read by him at the meeting.

We now again tell you that there are no seats and no desks in either the school room, the council room or the committee room, and the only fence built is 9' x 4' of pine.

There is no map case.

To the Hon. Dept. Gov. Gen. of Ind. Affairs,

Sir,

I received a copy of your letter by the Indian agent. And in reply would say I cannot understand why there is delay in the payment of my little account with this Band, in putting down concrete floor in the cellar of the Hall and Church.

Both the agent Mr. Wm. McFarlane and the architect Mr. Belcher of Peterboro had seen the water entering the cellar which would lay there for months causing the place very unclean and unhealthy. And advised the Band to do something to lay down concrete floors with its proper slope into the drain. Since all this was done there has been considerable fall of heavy rain in which water enters same as ever but with the proper slope from the walls on the floor.

Into the drain the water was carried off very readily and now there has been no water lying in the cellars of these buildings this fall or winter. There is also proper drainage underneath the concrete floors and laid down tile feeding from all directions into the drain. The cellars today are clean and healthy, but before this was done it was something disgraceful and unhealthy having water lying there on the clay floors for months. The Indian Department must think that this Band of Indians are all fools and don't know how to carry on their own business. If they did they are very much mistaken for there are Indians here who know as much about carrying on business as some of the members of the Indian Department. And if you could show me one instance where this
Indian council ever tried to defend
the Indian department. I would speak
differently. I have been easy with this
council by waiting for my payments
from the Indian funds. But, if this is
not paid by the end of this month,
February, I shall have to look for some
authority to assist me in collecting. Or
I think the council must have money
enough in their own council treasury
to pay the bill as I done at
satisfactory work for them which
they are greatly pleased, as they all claim
if this was not done this fall, there would been
again big washouts from under the foundation
walls in the spring, as it did last spring.
I hope this will be a little more soon as
I'm getting sick of this Tom fooling.

I received your letter dated 25th
of Feb. 1909, and in reply would say that
I have inquired into the case, with the chief.
And he claims that a resolution was
passed by the council early enough in the
spring and had forwarded the same to the
department through the agent, to give
the Indian Department plenty of time to
think and make their minds up to sanction
the resolution. Receiving no word from the
department or from the agent wrote again
in the fall to the agent. The agent & the
chief asking him if he thought these concrete
floors would cost more than a hundred
dollars. They came to me, as I have done
certain amount of laying concrete floors
and I told them I thought the floors
could be put down for $75.00 or $80.00.

Receiving no more word about it and the season was getting late, and seeing that the walls were damaged last year with the water, they thought it was advisable to lay the floor immediately. They came to me asked me to go ahead with the work at $75.00 and that they would see I got paid. I got the material ready cement and tile and then there came a heavy frost for over a week we had to wait until there came a thaw.

We got good weather for the work for about a week, so you could see it was getting late in the season for the job. But it was perhaps a great saving to the destruction of the buildings the coming season. I don't see why the Ind. Dept. cannot see fit to pay this account supposing they are not responsible.
Does not the Act say the Indians could use their money at any time for improvements to buildings on the reserve and is not this a great necessary improvement.

Why should not the Land Dept. pay this account when they are paying the school teacher $300.00 a year salary without the consent of the Band. This Band are only willing to pay the present teacher $200.00. We will have to get some capable man to see about our affairs if this account is not paid to land dept. Yours Truly

H.B. D.E. Whitney Jr.

These resolutions & questions should at least be answered more promptly to avoid any inconvenience.

D.E.W.J.

BUILDINGS and PREMISES.

The condition of school property is far from satisfactory. The building itself is a very substantial one and its architectural appearance is rather pleasing. In the planning of the interior, however, the interests of the school have been sacrificed to make room for other purposes. The class-room is very much too small for the accommodation of the pupils enrolled; it is ill ventilated, insufficiently lighted and improperly heated. At present the air supplied to the class-room is conveyed from a room malodorous from tobacco, spittoons and other filth. Later on, when the furnace is discontinued, and the room heated by a stove there will be absolutely no means of supplying fresh air to the class-room except by means of the windows. Some 30 odd children, in a room only half as large as it should be, without any ventilation and heated by an unjacketed stove, is a condition which can only be a menace to the community. The closets are, perhaps, the worst I have ever seen. They are too far away. There is absolutely no privacy and they are in a most filthy condition. On the invitation of the Chief, I am going out in the near future to discuss with the band the question of school improvement; and I hope that next year you may see a very marked improvement in the condition of this school.

(Sgd.) G.E.Broderick

Sir,

In reply to your letter dated Nov. 21st and No. 172211/5 referring to the visit of Mr. Inspector Brodie to Mud Lake School. I wish to say that I am well acquainted with Mr. Brodie and I will be pleased to meet him at Chemong anytime he may be fit to appear if at all possible.

Regarding the Water Closet at the school. On the occasion of each visit to the reserve I have warned the officers that they must have them cleaned and each time they promised to do so. I visited again on the 14th and found I was pleased when I arrived there to find that the Council had made arrangements to have them cleaned the next morning. I came over night and oversaw the work of cleaning myself. I find them thoroughly cleaned, scrubbed out and disinfected.

I must say I am at a loss to see—distance Mr. Brodie's assertion that the Closets are absolutely without privacy. If he means that persons by one the street can see a person going to or from the Closets, he is right; otherwise, I am compelled to give it an unqualified contradiction. They are built of native Lumber doors of the same a perfectly close partition between Girls' Closets and Boys' and high board fence guard out a few feet from the doors and supporting...
Sir—

The girls and boys in town. I am very sorry to have to contradict Mr. Brederich's idea—call the school perfectly private.

Regarding the school room it is small for the number of children, but they are not piled on top of one another at all. The ceiling is quite high there is an excellent foul air ventilator—a draft that will catch a piece of paper and hold it to the grate. Of course to Mr. Brederich's way there is no fresh air supply when the furnace is not firing except through the windows—the furnace is intended to heat the whole building. Hall, council house and school, and uses a large quantity of wood, for warming they use a small stove in school house. However there is very good window ventilation from wind to last through the council chamber, and here again I must say fair of Mr. Brederich. I have sat in the room at five council meetings and I thought it as clean as a council room usually is—in fact the first time I visited it I was struck with the clean appearance of it. During these council meetings some of the men chew tobacco and they use dishes with water in for spittoons—they do not smoke during the meeting, but so often it is overcome of them—Now if a person were only willing to put forth an effort to make
Sir,

In view of existing circumstances, one minute would suffice to throw a few shingles in those spots where there is a window or two and have good ventilation with a door between the two rooms to stop the draft at pleasure. But some people would sooner sit down and write letters to the Department on foul air than get up and open a window.

I have ordered a fanbelt for the stove and it was ready on Saturday. I intended fixing two windows in school room and two in council room, with ropes and pulleys so that they can be let down easier.

I would advise that nothing further be done till next season, as the Band have some idea of enlarging the old Church and using it as a hall—this hall is too small for their Council—therefore if they should do that then the present hall will be used for the school room and it will be twice the size of the present room.

I beg to enclose the account of Mr. J. McFarlane - Carpenter - for work done on the Mud Lake School. This is the last account in connection with this job, and the account may be closed. As the appropriation is considerably overdrawn, I wish to say that there were several things which I did not foresee when making the estimate, and which will form the most part accounts for the overdraw. REPORT OF INSPECTOR BRODERICK ON THE MUD LAKE DAY SCHOOL

I venture the opinion that it was a serious mistake to attempt to convert an ill constructed, cast-off church into a school building. The result is just what might have been predicted—a wretched failure. The lighting is very, very bad. The heating is also very bad, partly because the new windows are a misfit and there are no stern windows, partly because the stove is perhaps insufficient heating capacity for the room and partly because of utterly insufficient draft. This inadequate draft comes from stove pipe too long, imperfect chimney and from the fact that the chimney is connected up with a supposed ventilating system. Of course, there cannot possibly be any ventilation under present conditions.

The outbuildings could not well be worse than they are. The girls' building and the boys under one roof, without screened approaches and separated by only a thin board partition. It would be difficult to have conditions more favorable to immorality.

SUGGESTIONS—

1. A new building erected immediately behind the school with a space of 12 feet between. The building to be constructed for wood shed and closets from a plan which I shall be pleased to submit if requested.

2. A new chimney built of capacity to serve as ventilator as well as smoke flue.

3. A properly jacketed stove with fresh air flue from outside connected up so as to give proper heating and ventilation.

4. Adequate window space so as to give ample light. At present the light space is utterly insufficient.

Date of Inspection.—May 3rd, 1916.
With reference to the Chemong school house, I beg to say that there are a few changes required that would make a great improvement and add to the comfort of the school. At present the stove is in one corner of the room and with certain kinds of weather the pipe smokes. I would recommend that the stove be placed in the center just in front of the present entrance door from the cloak room, and that this door be closed up and two doors cut out from the cloak room one at each side. The girls coming in one door and the boys the other.

There is also some new pipes required perhaps 20. I estimate the improvements at $25.00. I don't think it would cost any more and I would recommend that it be done as soon as possible before the cold weather comes.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Building and premises are altogether unsuitable for school purposes. The grounds are too small and ill-shaped and unsuitable as a playground. The ground is, besides, made hideous by a dilapidated shed in the rear.

The school house, judged from any point, has not a single advantage. In that Indian community there is a fine brick church, occupied one hour a week and a fine brick "Council Building" which might easily have been modified and made to accommodate the school. Why the old cast-off church should have been converted into a school building is impossible to understand. And why the "repairs" should have taken the form they did is equally hard to understand. It was evidently not the work of anyone who knows anything about school buildings. There is no language too strong in condemnation of this building. There is no pretense at proper heating. There is a pretense to get proper lighting and proper ventilation. Neither the one nor the other has been secured. An effort was made to have a main light from one side of the class room. But the light is altogether insufficient and it is from the wrong side of the room. But the light is altogether insufficient and is from the wrong side of the pupils.

As to ventilation there is none.

No cloakrooms, no water supply.

But as to conditions inside and out, of the building itself the outbuildings are worse. At the back of the ground there is a building that serves as a closet. Both closets are under one roof and are separated by only a thin board partition. There is nothing—absolutely nothing—to give privacy. Having said this I have said enough.

Date of Inspection—February 24th, 1919.

GENERAL REMARKS—

Steps be taken to secure a proper site and erect a suitable school building as soon as possible so that the children of the Band may have all the advantages which such a building would afford.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, informing the Department that Miss Viola Lewis, who was recently appointed assistant teacher at the Mud Lake Indian Day School, began duties on the 4th instant.

Relative to the classroom furnishings, I beg to say that the school desks and teacher's table and chair were shipped by Messrs. J. Oliver & Sons, here, addressed to Chief D. E. Whetung, via C.N.R., Peterboro, Ont., at the beginning of the present week. It is hoped that this furniture has arrived and that it will be delivered at the school at an early date.

With reference to the blackboard, I beg to say that this was shipped by express from Montreal on December 11th, addressed to Chief D. E. Whetung, Peterboro, Ont. I am not certain by what express company the above was forwarded, but you should have Chief Whetung get in touch with the two express companies, as this shipment, no doubt, reached Peterboro sometime ago.

We note you state that you have purchased an additional teacher's desk and several other small articles. In view of the fact that a table and teacher's chair are being forwarded from here with the school desks, the teacher's desk ordered by you may not be required unless you can use it in one or other of the classrooms.

It is hoped that the assistant teacher can carry on until such time as the furnishings for her classroom arrive.

Your obedient servant,
